div.q: But this I confesse unto thee, that after the way which they call Heresie, So worship I the God of my Fathers, beleeving all things which are written in the Law and the Prophets, Act. 24. 14.

div.head: SOME CHOYCE FLOVVERS OF MASTER WALKERS RHETORICKE FOR THE READER TO SMELL ON BY THE WAY.

list.item: THe Confutation of the false exposition made by Socinus, and other Heretikes his Disciples, as Wotton, Goodwin, and their companions. pag. 18.
His Socinian Discourse. pag. 26.
He shewes himselfe as bold in affirming untruths, as ignorant both of Rhetoricke and Logicke, pag. 28.
A more odious example of impuden • ie and follie cannot bee imagined, then hee here makes himselfe, by making his folly and absurditie to strive for mastership with his impudence. pag. 4 • .
Thus he shamefully trifles to shew his impudencie and perversenesse. pag. 40.
This his confession is not out of humilitie and modestie, but out of Satanicall subtiltie, to vent his poysonfull lies under the person of another, as the Devill did vent his by the Serpent. pag. 40.
I easily gather from his impudent boldnesse. ibidem. And a little after his impudent boasting.
He shewes himselfe a bold lying Sophister. pag 29.
Here we have a heape of lies mixt with contradictions. pag. 31.
Here like a mad or drunken man, he contradicts himselfe. ibid.
His words are most wicked and blasphemous. pag. 32.

This opinion being built upon such hereticall and blasphemous
grounds, and maintained by such blasphemous arguments, must needes be most impious, hereticall, and blasphemous. pag. 26.
I will not have such a forger and false suborner of witnesses to goe away without the brand of forgerie, and notorious impudencie, pag. 43.

The very Father of lyers, the Devill himselfe, should if not blush and be ashamed, yet in policie be afraid to call Calvin for a witnesse, lest all that heare him, should hate and hisse him for his open lying. p. 50.

Let zealous Christians consider, whether it bee not their dutie, both to take heede to themselves, and admonish others, that they have no fellowship with so openly profest Socinian Sectaries, as this man and his followers are: you see the Doctrine they maintaine is wicked and blasphemous Heresie: And presently after, they still persist in their pestilent heresie, and are more mad to maintaine and disperse it,—they flee for helpe to the Father of lie: and in forging lies they sinne, being condemned of themselves against their knowledge & conscience; as the Apostle fore told concerning Heretickes. And againe immediately after: How wilfully against the knowne truth, and his owne conscience, this desperate man hath proclamed Luther, &c. Againe: As for his rude, impudent, and unmannerly followers, their owne lying and slanderous tongues proclame their pedigree from the Father of lyers. pag. 55. From such lying spirits, &c. pag. ult.

Thus you see how he hath bent his tongue and pen like a bow for lies, and shoots them forth thicke and threefold like poysoned arrowes, as if his quiver were the armory of the Father of lyars, the Prince of darkenesse. pag. 35.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: SOme weekes since there was sent unto mee, from a worthy Gentleman (a friend of mine) a Tract in writing, of somewhat a distracted subject, method, and expression, without any Authors name unto it. Though I could not then be so confident, that Master Walker was the Authour, as I then was, (and still am) that the opinion (whatsoever it be) that seekes maintenance in it, but findes none, is a supine & fond errour (I forbeare to call it Heresie, Blasphemie, or the like, lest my Antagonist knowing so well my ignorance in Rhetoricke, should boast, that I was beholding to him for his) yet had I a very reasonable and strong perswasion, that he was the man, and no other. And this I was induced to beleeve, the rather (besides divers other grounds of this apprehension) because I finde the image and character of the man, so fairely and significantly stamped upon it, viz. words, and passion. Nec lac lacti, nec ovo ovum similius: vnum qui nôrit, ambos noverit.

lg.l: Not milke to milke, nor egg to egg more like,
Then booke to man, and man againe to booke.

div.p:
Some monethes before, upon the clamorous, uncessant, and insulting importunity of some, who were confident (it seemes) of finding shelter under Mr. W s. wing for some opinions they held and loved dearely (though they little deserved it) and would not trust so bad a cause in the hand of any other Champion (their owne word and stile they gave him) I was requested and much pressed from time to time by some of my acquaintance, that if I could at any time spare a day, I would goe over to Mr. W. to consider and reason
some points, depending (as it seemed) in sharpe dispute among themselves. Why Mr. W. amongst all the Divines in Citie or Countrey, should be so importunely pitched upon by those men, I leave to those that know him, to consider: onely thus farre (as I was informed) they discovered themselves, that they little thought or expected, I either would or durst looke such a champion as he in the face. In which conceipt of my unwillingnesse & fearefulnesse to appeare before him, Mr. W. himselfe was partaker with them, and lost a wager of fiveshillings (as himselfe consessed) upon it. Whereby it appeares, that these men had such an opinion or hope of him, that there was some knowne propertie in him, which should make sober men and of few words afraid to come neere him in a way of disputation; which whether it bee the depth of his learning, the sharpenesse of his wit, activenesse in disputing, or some other thing, I will not divine, but had rather others should conjecture, then I determine. At last (not without much gainesaying from my other occasions and imployments) I sacrificed a day upon the service of Mr W s. reputation, and went to him▪ to conferre with him about the points in question betweene his friends and mine, and to receive further information from him therein, if hee had had any of this commodity in his hand. But my going to him was upon the same termes, and with like successe that Christ went to the figtree, Mat. 21. who found no fruit thereon, but leaves onely. The conference betweene us being managed in a tumultuous and issuelesse manner, the one of us still carrying aside the state of the Question, and hiding it in a great thicket and wildernesse of words, and no waies willing to heare or understand, what the opinion was, wherein satisfaction was desired: I was desired at last, both by Mr. W s. owne brother, (the Minister of the place, in whose house wee were) and by divers others unknowne to me then present (well-willers, as I conceived, both to peace and truth) to leave something in writing, whereby the state of the question or controversie betweene us, might be the more steadily and distinctly knowne and judged of. The day being farre spent, and opportunity otherwise wanting for setting downe
then in writing, what I judged convenient and necessary for such a purpose, and having casually about me a paper of some collections I had formerly made concerning the interpretatiō of such passages in the fourth chapter to the Romans, as concerned the businesse betweene us, this I left behind me, with a faire and ingenuous promise and protestation, that if either Mr. W. or any other, could give me a distinct and cleare accompt, how those passages might with any tollerable congruity of reason and consistence with other Scriptures of like argument, bee carried in their interpretation, to comply with the opinion held by some against me; I would willingly acknowledge any such satisfaction, and let my present judgement and opinion fall. Therefore whereas Mr. W. complaines page 27. of his discourse (as of some injurie done to him, or affront put upon him) that hee should bee challenged to answer those reasons I left with him, I dare not absolutely deny, himselfe affirming it, but that hee might bee challenged (least ignorance, impudence, lying, heresie, blasphemie and such furies, Mr. W s. familiars, should presently be about my eares for it) but this I confidently affirme (yet without any impudence at all) that if Mr. W. were so challenged, it was by him, who long fince appeared to Saul in Samuells likenesse, and of late (it seemes) hath appeared to Mr. W. and given him this challenge. Those few notes I left with him, have proved very fruitfull and generative: they are returned into my bosome with an abundant increase. Yet unhappy they have been in their propagation: they have not begotten in their image or likenesse. I doe not remember that any one line amongst them was possessed with any such tragicall, truculent or Gorgonean spirit, as breathes fire & furie in a great part of that long discourse occasioned by them. Why Mr. W. should write so much upon so small an occasion, I impute to the abundance of his time and leasure above mine, who may (I conceive) drop weekes and moneths against my houres, in the fulnesse of an estate temperance (we know) is more then an ordinary vertue. Why he should write so much to so little purpose, I am loath to impute to any infirmitie or defect in him, whereby he should be disabled
from discerning, when either himselfe or others, speake shells, or kernells: I will rather impute it to some such politique and profound reach in him as this; knowing my leasure to be little to attend such eccentricall & by-businesse as this is, his device might be to oppresse and overcharge my time with reading, that so I might be straightned, if not wholly cut off from answering. And the truth is, that the bulkinesse or body of the discourse, is the life and soule of it, it being more troublesome to reade, then to answer. But what should so transcendently sublimate the choler of the man, to raile right downe such milstones of obloquies, reproches, calumnies, curses upon my head, I cannot imagine; except it were the fairenesse of my writing, and fewnesse of my words when I was with him: both which having an energeticall and pregnant antipathy to an angry temper, and talking disposition, might (I confesse) by way of an antiperistasis, provoke and inflame their contrary natures in him. Other cause (besides these) on my part, I verily know none, except (happily) that also might be a sparke falling into his gunpowder, that I desired him once and againe, when we were together, that hee would clearely and distinctly lay downe, what his opinion was, in opposition to what was maintained by me. Himselfe indeede, in the presence of some both of his friends and mine, (who were partly requested, and partly offered themselves to goe over to him, to mediate with him for a peace, or at lest for termes of a fairer warre, after he had begunne the fight in this furious manner) drew the pedegree and royall descent of his quarrell against me, from an ancient meeting betweene us in Cheap-side, some three or foure yeares since (to my remembrance, I know not how long before any thing was thought of concerning the dispute now depending) at which meeting (as the partie aggrieved in effect complaineth) I did not doe my homage to his discourse with that reverence and gravity which became me, but either smiled or laughed at it; I am not conscious to my self of any such prodigious oversight, but since I was challenged for it▪ I have enquired after my error by as many as I have met with, of those that were then present with us, and can heare no tydings of it at any hand.
If I had made any breach upon Mr. W •. reputation, either in that kinde or in any other, upon conviction, I should have been ready (and still am) to have repaired it with the best of mine owne. But I feare, Mr. W. had rather take revenge, then satisfaction: and by his owne confession of the roote and originall of his quarrell against me, it may easily be perceived, how good and faithfull a treasurer he is of the black Princes coyne; these three or foure yeares together he hath sat brooding a Cockatrice egge, and now at last the fiery flying Serpent is come forth. But this by the way. At my late being with him about the point in Question, in stead of cleering his opinion, when he was desired and pressed thereunto, he still interposed a dark cloud of words, and quite buried his minde under his tongue. And when wee should have met about our businesse in the East, and were upon the point of grapling and closing, he immediately hoyseth up sayle, and tacks about againe to the West, as if he had been affrighted with his owne opinion or shadow, and had resolved never to come neere it. And to this day, what his opinion cleerly is in opposition to me in this controversie, I am at perfect peace in my thoughts, that himselfe yet understandeth not. I have this ground (among others) for what I say, because a man may as well find a needle in a bottle of hay, as finde any such opinion, either cleered, or constantly maintained, in this his discourse, which yet was penned by him purposely in confutation of my (erroneously so called) errour. Surely his opinion, (what ever it be) is very melancholique, and (according to the character of that humour) 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , either a God, or a beast. And he deales by it accordingly: for he onely shewes the backside of it to the world, and is either ashamed to have the feature, shape, and face of it seene, as if it were some Monster: or else he judgeth the world, either unworthy or unable, to behold the glory of it, and so meant tacitely to insinuate some Numen or Deitie in it.

I will first tell you, what I call the backside of his opinion: and then what I meane by the fore-side, or face. The backside of his opinion, I call those generall, lax, and wide expressions, wherein (and wherein onely) he expresseth himselfe in his discourse, as, viz. That Beleevers have communion with Christ; That Faith is not our Righteousnesse; that the righteousnesse and satisfaction of Christ are imputed to us; that we are justified by Christs righteousnesse, and such like. In which positions, if his meaning be no worse then his words, (though some of them be incommodious, & of no affinitie with Scripture expressions in this point) I neither ever was, nor yet am, nor (I hope) ever shall be an adversary to him. I call these the backside of his opinion, because they doe onely in a generall, confused, and indistinct manner represent his judgement in this controversie, and upon such termes, that a man may easily carry away his words, and yet leave his opinion behind him, as it is an easie matter to mistake one man for another, when their backs onely are toward us. But 2o, if Master Walker had any mind to shew us the face of his opinion, he should tell us distinctly, roundly, and plainly, what righteousnesse of Christ he means should be imputed to us for righteousnesse, and how, and after what manner, and upon what termes it is imputed, as viz. Whether by vertue of such imputation, a man be made legally righteous, so that he may claime Heaven in right of the first Covenant, Doe this and live: or whither, by Christs righteousnesse imputed to us, he meanes nothing else, but our being justified by the vertue or merit of those things, which Christ hath done and suffered for us? He that doth not in this controversie, punctually, and precisely explaine himselfe, in these particulars, rather conceales and covers, then discovers his opinion. If Mr W. at any time seemes to make some slender explication of himselfe in some of these particulars, he soone misfigures againe his owne expression with words of manifest inconsistency therewith: so that the setled judgement of the Author in the Question controverted, must be some where else inquired after, then in his discourse: This I can say of mine own knowledge, that when I was with him, pressing him to know, whither by the righteousnesse of Christ
(in his opinion) he meant the righteousnesse of his nature, consisting of inward habits or dispositions of grace and holinesse; or the righteousnesse of his life, consisting of those righteous acts, which he performed in obedience to the Law of God, or whither he included them both, he absolutely denied, that he meant either the one or the other, or both together. The same deniall, I heard, he had formerly made to another (who put the same, or like question to him) with some ill language uttered against me, that I should goe about to perswade my followers, that either he or any other of his judgement in this question, should so conceive. Being further pressed to declare himselfe, whither his meaning then was, that any such righteousnesse of Christ were imputed to us, which Christ himselfe never had (no other righteousnesse of Christ, either as man, or Mediator, being imaginable but onely the two former) here he brake off with some such shuffling expression as this, that he held, it was a humane righteousnesse that was imputed from Christ unto us, and would heare no more on that eare. If any man out of all this, and ten times more in his discourse to helpe him, can make out the riddle of Mr W s. opinion, I doe not envie him the mystery of his knowledge: but for my part (whither it be my ignorance in Logique, or in Rhetorique, I cannot tell) my soule cannot find the way to enter into his secret. The best that I can make of his opinion, from his words and writings together, is this; that that Righteousnesse of Christ, which was none of Christs righteousnesse, is imputed to us for our righteousnesse, in our justification. Which conclusion if he can fetch off roundly, and like a man, from the Scriptures, I presently yeeld him the Bucklers, and will be no longer his corrivall—Sed Phillida solus habebit: that is, He shall faire Phillis have alone.

I deny not, but some may possibly be convinc'd and satisfied by his discourse: but certainly, they must be such as stand in a precipitate and headlong disposition to his opinion before hand. I professe, I scarce ever met with any man, that being so weake and contemptible in his premisses, fell so sore and heavy in his conclusions. I acknowledge that going about to reply, I transgeresse a grave precept which I learn'd
long since out of Cato—Contra verbosos noli contendere verbis; Which may be well enough translated in our English Proverb, It is no gaping against an Oven. Notwithstanding, because such a truth of God, as occasioned that loud discourse is above the s • here of Cato's wisdome or precepts, I have rather chosen to endanger my selfe the second time, for the honour and preservation thereof, then to provide for mine owne peace or repute, by betraying such a piece of Heaven into the hand of an enemy. I confesse, I never yet made tryall of my strength, in shooting in M• W s. bow, (I meane in rayling and reviling) neither am I so in love with the exercise, that I should intend ever to doe it: yet, me thinks, if I would set to it, I could draw an arrow as neere the head in it, as Mr. W. himselfe hath done: or if my owne strength and abilitie in this should fayle me, I make no question, but I might have ready assistance from him, who (I dare say) hath not stood at my adversaries right hand to resist him in that service he hath done against God and his truth, in this expedition. But the truth, neither desireth nor needeth any goods so ill gotten. What depths of learning, wit or judgement, men of more raised understandings and sublimated apprehensions may finde, in that boysterous, unchristian, and inhumane Dialect, meeter for the disputes of Jjm and Oijm, then for theirs that call themselves the Ministers of Jesus Christ, wherein his discourse is written, I know not: neither doe I desire to damnifie or prejudice Mr. W. in any part of his reputation with such men. But for my selfe, I looke and looke as narrowly, as unpartially as I can, and yet can find no depths in such learning, but onely the depths of Machiavell. Indeed his beloved Maxime, in case of opposition was; Calumniare audacter, aliquid haerebit, that is, Calumniate thy adversary stoutly; something will stick by him in despite of him, let him doe what he can to wipe it off. But otherwise▪ for matter of learning, who knows not, that the weakest braine in both Universities, is as able as Mr. W. himselfe, to cry out against any man, Socinian, Arminian, ignorant, impudent, lyar, lying Sophister, Heretique, Blasphemer, a man of a Satanicall spirit, &c. The Scribes and Pharisees had no fellowes, in traducing Christ himselfe, for a seducer,
a deceiver, a Blasphemer, a Bellzebub. A man needs not have a great study full of bookes nor looke pale and wan with much reading or studying, to furnish himselfe with foule language; birds of this feather will come flying fast enough without a s • rapp.

When I left my papers with Mr. W. I was in hope, that I had put my selfe into the hand of a Minister of Jesus Christ, which though I dare not yet denie him to be, yet in the favourablest construction that can bee made of his proceedings, he is one of the strangest Ministers of Christ that a man shall lightly heare of. That a Minister of Satan should transforme himselfe into an Angell of light (as Paul speaketh) holds a rationall proportion and consistence, both with the shame and reproach of sinne, and with the glory of righteousnesse: neither is it much to bee marvelled at, that men should seeke to hide deformitie under an appearance of lovelinesse and beauty. But that a Minister of Christ should transforme himselfe into the likenesse of an Angel of darkenesse, and besmeare the brightnesse of his face with the grease and soote of hell, is the most unnaturall metamorphosis that ever was heard of.

When Michael the Archangell disputed with the Devill about the body of Moses, hee durst not bring against him a railing accusation. Jude verse 9. Therefore (doubtlesse) Mr. W. must either make himselfe greater then the Archangel, or me worse then the Devill, or both; or else he hath foulely miscarried in a great and weighty duty of Christianity. It may be he can deliver himselfe roundly without any scruple of conscience, out of these straights: it is but thrusting mee downe a degree beneath Lucifer, and then his mouth is wiped cleane, he hath done nothing. God forbid that I should upbraid any man with his sufferings: God and Mr. W. and some other good enemie-friends, have put me (of late) into the liverie of the company of sufferers; but I see that it was not the crosse that Dysmas (if that was his name) hung on, that brought him to repentance, but hee that was crucified with him. And Cyprian reports of some that had suffered, who grew worse and more insolent afterwards.

If Mr. W. had an intent or desire to have gained ground upon me, or led me away in triumph, hee was quite mistaken in the method of his warre. Five sober words well ballanced with reason and understanding, would have gone further with me, and wounded me deeper then a thousand crackers, or the raging, reasonlesse, roarings of ten thousand Belzeebubs. I regard no more the rage or rubbidge of any mans tongue, (though in many degrees of outward greatnesse and power, Mr. Ws. superiour) then I doe the dung that passeth from him. But if any man speakes reason (though he bee as many degrees his inferiour) I am ready to tremble, and to doe him reverence. Therefore Mr. W. might have kept his earth-quakes and whirlewinds and fires, and sold them for bugbeares to scare children: his still voyce would soone have layed mee at his feet. I dare not (indeede) deale with him, or answer him at his owne weapon (I meane railing) how ever provoked: the yoke that Christ hath put about my necke to keepe me in compasse this way, I dare not breake nor cast from mee. Neither doe I know any example in all the Historie of Heaven, that would beare mee out in such a practise And therefore I heare promise him (and will keepe promise too, for his learning) that throughout all my Reply, I will neither call him Socinian, nor Arminian, nor Hereticke, nor Blasphemer, nor Lyer, nor lying Sophister, nor Impudent fellow, or the like. It may be I may now and then (but very rarely) administer the infusion of some of these simples, but will never give the grosse substance I shall deale with him in a more ingenuous way. I hope, that having taken a liberty in folio to speake evill of me undeservedly, hee will not be a man of so hard a conscience, as not to give me leave in decimo sexto to make merry with him. If hee gives mee gall and vinegar to drinke, and I requite him with plesant wine, I trust hee shall have no cause (in the judgement of any reasonable man to complaine.) Though I cannot meete with any faithfull servant of God in all that long roade that lyeth betweene Genesis the first, and the first▪ and Revelations the last, and the last, in a railing or reviling posture, but onely Shimei's, Rabsecah's, and such like sons of B • lial: Yet I finde that holy strict and
severe Prophet himselfe (Elijah I meane) in present discourse with the sleepie God Baal, and his zealous and slashing Priests, 1 Kings 18. 17. And David (wee know) had many troubles, trialls, difficulties, dangers, pressures, Doegs, Achitophels, tongues as sharpe as rasors, and that cut like swords upon him, from time to time: yet hee contriv'd all into matter of musicke and songe▪ and played them off upon his Harpe. There was a speciall necessity lying upon mee, to carry this businesse recreation-wise (as neere as I could) because I had little other tyme for the dispatch of it, then what my health repuired of me in some way of respiration & refreshing from my constant and standing labour.—Quanquam ridentem dicere verum,—Quid vetat? that is;

lg.l: A man in mirth the truth may say,
As well as in a sadder way.

div.p:
My first thoughts were upon the first sight and appearance of my adversaries blacke Genius, onely to have reprooved and chide Sathan (for the worke he had made) and to have let Mr. W. alone, onely presenting him with those words from the mouth of an Archangell, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . The Lord rebuke the. But considering that some of his readers (for the citie I heard ran quicke betymes with the dispersed copies of his most vincible Answer) before my turne came to see it) might (haply) bee so farre mistaken in him, as to thinke him Iupiter, because of the terrible appearance of his thunder and lightning, and not Salmonerus the Iugler.
Qui tonitru Iovis, & flammas imitatur Olympi, that is;
Who counterfeits the cracks of thundring Iove,
And flashing flames of the th' Heavens from above:

I thought it the safer way, and wherein the truth might suffer lesse, to be somewhat larger, and to give the world a tast of his deepe non-sight in the Question under dispute, and of his truth and faithfulnesse in these proceedings. The law agreed
upon for this dispute betweene us (as I thinke Mr. W •. his brother remembreth, who either was himselfe the first propounder and mover for it, or else some other Minister then in presence with us) was that passages should be private betweene our selves, and not communicated ad extrà: yet divers weekes, before mine eyes could see, mine eares heard, that Mr. W •. pictures (I meane the coppie of his pamphlet) were up and downe the citie in severall hands, his picture in gold, and mine in lead at his feet. Yet in this I can partly excuse him: for being naturally a sub-angry man, it is like that his promise and hee fell out by the way, and were at odds, and so could not walke together to their journeyes end.

For my method in transacting this businesse with him, I shall not strike, as oft as I finde him naked: I should then overcharge my Reader, with inke and paper, (whatsoever I have done now) which is a pressure I have sufferd my selfe under him. I may cover a multitude of infirmities, and yet have sufficient to worke upon besides. I shall onely here and there, where the occasion is the ranker, apply some animadversions: yet so, that the Reader shall finde, every thing that deserves an answer (yea, and many things, which indeede deserved it not) fully sifted and examined. In these my animadversions, I still make reference (in the margin) to the severall passages of that copie of his Answer, which was sent unto mee, for the finding out those passages, to which I doe more particularly frame my reply. And were it not for labour or charge of writing, I could wish that hee that shall please to peruse these notes and observations upon his Answer, might have a copy of the Answer it selfe by him, to read (occasionally) the entire passages of things there, which I was loath to transcribe at large in my reply. Notwithstanding to save my Reader that labour and charge, without any materiall losse or damage of the matters betweene us, I have transcribed many things verbatim out of the answer, from place to place; which makes my Reply so much the more bulkie▪ and overladen with words.

Vpon the receipt of his Answer, before I proceeded in this
Reply, I wrote a letter to him by some of my friends, partly to know the certaintie concerning the Answer, whether he would owne it, or no: partly to give him a friendly opportunity and intimation of making cleane where he had fouled therein (I meane of retracting his foule and unseemely language) before my pen came to tread in it, and so to make it stinck to his shame and infamie in the world. The copie of which letter I have here transcribed immediately after this preface. But as David complained of his enemies, that they rewarded him evill for good, to the spoyling of his soule, Psalme 35. so my severe and implacable adversarie, Mesechlike, when I was for peace, he was for warre: and in stead of the least relenting of his discrologie, or any waies comporting with my motion that way, he entertayned the Messenger • that were sent unto him, with such magnificant presents of further railing, reviling, & horrid imputations against me, as if he had been newly returned from the slaughter of Rabsecah, or had the same day divided the spoyles of hell. My desire and intent is, rather to make merry with my Antagonist, then to complie with him in his passion, or to be angry, because he is angry: yet I know not, whether it may not bee the greater rack and torture to him, to bee put to it to be angry alone.

The great God of Heaven and earth, by whom I must bee judged (and that I know not how soone or suddenly) as well concerning my carriage in this businesse, as the other acts of my life, knoweth that I stand cleare and free in my heart and spirit to the man (notwithstanding his seven fold provocation) wishing him no more evill, then I doe to my selfe, or my own soule, and am ready at an houre, upon the acknowledgement of his oversight, to give him the right hand of fellowship at any time. Onely having wronged the truth (as hee hath done) it cannot be but such injuries will be chargeable to him: howsoever, Repentance will bring him into his owne againe, with advantage.

div.head: The Copie of my Letter sent to Mr. Walker, upon the Receipt of his Answer, seeking either peace from him, or a faire warre.
div.p:
SIR, a few dayes since there was sent unto me, from a Gentleman (a Friend and Neighbour of mine) a Manuscript of about 21 leaves in quarto, which though I have not yet had time (by reason of full imployments otherwise) fully to peruse, yet casting my eye here and there, by some passages I conjecture the piece to be yours. Wherein also I am somewhat the further confirmed, by the common rumor abroad in the Citie, and which came to my eares severall weeks, before I Received the Writing, that your Answer to my Reasons, were in the hands of many. Yet two things there are, that make me at some stand in my thoughts, whither the discourse be yours, or no; at least, whither it be come to me, as it came from you; or whither rather it be not some Libell, wherein both you and my selfe may be abused together. The one is, because there is no name at all of any Author put to it▪ which (you know) is Libell-like. The other is, the many veins of unsavoury and foule language, which run here and there through the body of the Discourse. If the piece be yours, I cannot but suspect, that your Scribe, to whom you committed the transcribing of it, hath some wayes wronged you, by mingling your milk with
blood, and defacing your intellectualls, with his patheticalls. It will not readily enter into me, that so uneven and course a thrid should be of Mr Walkers spinning. Wherefore my request in love to you is, that you will please to signifie, either by writing or otherwise; whither the discourse be yours, or no, whole and intire, good and bad together, as it came to my hands: or whither onely that which is somewhat rationall and Christian in it, be yours: but for the rough Turkie dialect, as, Socinian, Arminian, lyar, lying Sophister, impudent fellow, Heretique, Blasphemer, a man of a Satanicall spirit, cum id genus monstris, you are willing to disavow. Because, that if there be a necessitie, that for the truths sake, I must have warres with you, I desire they may be Christian and fayre, such as may tend to establish and settle the truth in peace, with as little blood-shed of the names and reputations of the Combatants, as may be. Thus desiring you to send me backe the Paper I left in your hands, with the tender of my respects and love unto you, I recommend you to the grace and love of God in his Christ.

closer.signed: Your loving Brother in the work of Jesus Christ; J. G.

div.head: ANIMADVERSIONS Vpon some of the looser and fowler passages in Mr. WALKERS Discourse entitled, A DEFENCE of the true sence and meaning of the words of the holy Apostle, Rom. 4. 3. 5. 9. &c.
div.p: A DEFENCE of the true sence, &c. The manM. W. p. 1. 2. hath well said in promising a defence of the true sence of any Scripture. Oh that there were a heart and understanding in him to performe it accordingly: I would strive to outrun all MR. Walkers Disciples in my respects, and honour to him. But they that made and worshipped the Golden Calfe, honoured it and styled it with the Name of a God, These are thy Gods, O Israel &c. So is it not much to be wondered at, if MR. Walker, having made and taken unto himselfe the figure of a false interpretation, doth the best be can to honour and grace it before the world▪ with the rich Style of The true sence and meaning &c. There was never any man that went about to adulterate the Kings Coyne, and to put off copper for Gold, but carefully provided for that, that Carolus Rex Dei gratia &c. should be stamped in as faire a Character upon it, as is to be found upon any piece comming out of the Kings Mint.

But the mans heart presently begins to fall under the greatnesse of his enterprise: in the very first clause of his Discourse, he abates much of his confidence in the title. For that which was there, the true sence and meaning of the Apostle (simply) is here only The true sence with limitation, viz. according to the Common judgement of the most godly, learned, and judicious Divines, of the best Reformed Churches, &c. Now wee know that sometimes there is (and oftner may bee then we are aware of) as great a difference betweene the true sence and meaning of a Scripture, and the judgement of the most godly, and learned Divines, as is betweene Heaven and Earth, yea the judgement of the most godly, learned, and judicious Divines, hath sometimes stood at that distance from the true sence and meaning of some Scriptures, that they have rejected the Scriptures themselves, upon a conceit that they contayned things in them contrary to their judgements, and apprehensions. This heavy censure, that notable and rare piece of Divine inspiration, the Booke of the Revelation suffered, even from the most godly, and learned Divines the Church of God had in it about the second or third Century after Christ, being generally disclaimed as Apocryphall and irreptitious▪ It were easie to cite instances in abundance of great variance, and dissention betweene the judgments of Divines, of Master Walkers qualification, and the true sence and meaning of many Scriptures: and yet hee that saith and knoweth all this, may reverence the uniforme judgements of such Divines, touching the sence of Scriptures, as much (or more) then Master Walker himselfe doth.

Well: but yet he bewrayeth some consciousnes, or timorousnes in his undertaking, though thus qualified and explained. He doth not loosely say, that the sence of these Scriptures, which he undertakes to defend, is the sence given by most Godly Divines, but with caution upon caution, thus: accord • ng to the common iudgement of the most godly, and of the best Reformed Churches. Whether
by the most godly, learned, and iudicious Divines, he meanes the greater part, or number of Divines that are godly, learned, &c. or whether onely those that are most eminent amongst and above their Fellowes, for godlines, learning, &c. he wisely leaves unexplained: that in case the one sence should oppresse him, he might make the other his friend to releive him. If hee desires to be understood in the former sence (which is the more honest, obvious, and direct of the two) then I feare he will be as hardly put to it for voyces amongst Reformed Divines, as the Pope was in the Councell of Trent, and must take some such course to make Authors, as he did Bishops. As for Luther, Calvin, Musculus, Bullinger &c. They will not come over to him with his whistling: except (haply) he hath a secret pack of Authors, of the same Names, but of different judgements, with those that are commonly knowne by their Names, in the World. And it should seeme (indeed) he hath some such unknowne advantage, for page 50. hee citeth wordes out of Calvins Institutions, which in my exemplar are not to be found in the place cited. And p 41. he tels a tale out of St. Bernard's 190. Epistle concerning one Peter Abilaird (as his Scribe nameth him) which I beleeve is not to be found in that Epistle, except it be in his own Book. If the latter sence should be intended by him (which yeelds the best shadow for him to shelter himself under) it will be hard (I confesse) to evict him in this; because it must then first be decided (which will never be but by a generall Councell, and yet I thinke as soone without it, as with it) which, or who in all that great retinue and equipage of Reformed Divines, have the preheminence above all their fellowes, in all those three incomparable qualifications, Godlinesse, learning, Judgement. For as Seneca saith well. Non est admirationi una arbor, ubi totum Nemus in eandem altitudinem surrexit. And except there be some one or more amongst them, who is more excellent then all his Neighbours, in all the three rare endowments
specified (which is most unlikely: for excellencies commonly walke single, and not by troupes, or companies, in the World) then hath Master Walker undertaken nothing at all, concerning the judgement of Reformed Divines according with him, in the sence he gives of these Scriptures. But howsoever, hee himselfe begins betimes to stumble at that Stone, (which afterwardes he chides me very sharply for stumbling at, though it be onely in his apprehension, and I make question whether even there also) viz. Ambiguities in disputation: and I would be loath to trouble my selfe with taking him up every time, he falls on this hand, in his discourse. Sure I am (whether it be my example, or his own, he followes so close, I know not) that he speakes little better then ambiguously in the greatest part of this tract: except it be where either he speakes manifest untruths, or good common sence, instead of reason. As immediately after, when he speakes of the most Godly, Learned, and indicious Divines of the best Reformed Churches, what Heyfer should a man plough with to find out his riddle in those wordes, the best Reformed Churches? who knowes in what order and Method the Reformed Churches are mustered and ranged in Mr. Wal. Booke of valuations of Churches? Quas quibus anteferat. Suppose we may probably conceive that hee takes the Reformed Church of England, for one of the best of these Churches, may we not as well cast lots, as conceive otherwise, to which of the other Churches, he will give the Honour of sitting at the right hand of the English? whether to the German, French, or Dutch Churches, or some other?

Besides, if hee should particularly declare himselfe, what and how many Reformed Churches he meanes, by the best: yet wee are little the neerer, knowing his mind concerning the Divines, whose judgements hee undertakes to associate with his owne, in the sence and meaning of these Scriptures. The best Reformed Churches
have not necessarily the most godly, learned, and judicious Divines in them. The sweetest showers may sometimes fall upon the rocks: and God is at liberty to blesse weaker and lower instruments, above the increase of those, that are more excellent and glorious. Therefore all this while no man can comprehend by what he hath said, what Divines should bee of his judgement in the interpretation of these passages: neither have wee any such cause to complaine, that wee are kept in suspense herein, because (as the saying is) nihil dat quod non habet, that is, nothing gives, but what it haves: it is good manners for us to be served after himselfe. I beleeve he hath no great assurance himselfe of any in this kind. When his confidence this way comes to him, I doubt not but we shall have it good cheap.

But what is the sence and meaning of these places, for the defence whereof he hath taken such hold of shield and buckler? I confesse he layes downe discourse enough to open seven mens mindes at once, in as much as the sence and meaning of these Scriptures comes to. But (whether it be my dulnesse or ignorance in his Rhetorick and Logick, whereof I am taxed sharply enough, and it may be, deservedly enough too, page 28. and page 37. of his answer) I have no skill of his Vlyssean Eloquence, when he powreth out words 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as thick as flakes of snow in Winter time; they make me as blind, as the Snow it selfe doth, when I travell in it. I cannot find out his Mole-hill of meaning for his Mountains of words. If all that he delivers in that multilineary Hyperbaton, be that sence and meaning which hee hath taken into his protection, surely I neither was, nor am his adversary, in farre the greatest part of it. So that for the true sence and meaning of the place, as he hath promised the defence thereof, so (I confesse) in some sence, he hath well and sufficiently performed. As Venus protected and defended her son Aeneas, when she put him into a cloud, where none could see him: so hath Mr.
W. abundantly provided for the safety and defence of the true sence of these Scriptures, that no man shall be able to finde it, or come at it to doe it any harme, by spreading such a thick and darke cloud of words round about it on every side, Surely he hath found the line and Plummet which the builders of Babel used in laying the corner stone of their Tower, and hath stretched it upon the foundation of this his Fabrick. Onely whereas (towards the end of this 2. page) he acknowledgeth and granteth, that upon Abrahams beleefe of the promise, God counted this unto him for righteousnesse; that is, accepted and accounted him for a righteous man: if he would not afterwards misuse his owne good wordes, with a bad meaning, for my part I should never say that black was his eye, in this Question. But this is frequently observed in men that are ingaged against the truth, that the truth sometimes will be too hard for them, and breake Prison before their keepers are aware of it. I passe by other things in this page, that well deserve virgulam Censoriam, my discourse will live and maintaine it selfe sufficiently, upon the tithes of Mr. Ws. errours, if they were but truely payd.

The corrupt exposition of the words by theMr. W. p. 2.
Heretick Socinus, the Arminians &c. Surely my Adversary hath heard of the most inhumane and unnaturall cruelty of the Tyrant Mezentius: and hath taken his practise in one piece of unmercifulnesse towards me from him, whose practise was this (as Virgil relateth it,)

q.l: Corponeris manibusque manus, at{que} oribus ora:

div.p:
He us'd to joyne and couple living and dead men together, with face to face, hands to hands, &c. and so to keepe them, or drag them about together, till the living found an end of his misery, by joyning hands
with his Companion in death. So Mr. Ws. intent in his necromanticall bringing up the dead Corpes of Socinus, and Arminius so often upon his Stage, is to bind mee hard, first to the one, and then to the other: and in this posture to drag me up and downe at his pleasure, that so by this unnaturall, and artificiall torment and shame, I might goe downe with sorrow into my grave. But the best is, he can find onely greene withs to bind mee withall, which will snap in sunder like a threed of tow, when it toucheth the fire: I have a sharpe knife about mee, called truth, that will presently deliver me out of these bands by cutting in sunder those cords of vanity, wherwith my enemy hath bound me. And if I tooke any pleasure in troubling my selfe that way, wherein my adversary (it seemes) takes singular delight and contentment, I could stretch his opinions in this controversie, upon Socinian and Arminian tenter-hookes, better cheap, and with lesse streyning by farre, then hee either doth or can doe mine. Yea I shall anon present you Arminius himselfe, with his mouth as full of Mr. W. opinion in the point of Imputation, as it can hold, without spilling. Yea (that which is yet more) if I sought any such bloudy revenge upon the man, I make no Question, but I could with the full leave and consent of his opinion, make him hold up his hand at the barre, and answer for those crimes of heresie and blasphemy, where & for which he hath so oft arraigned me, with the highest and cleerest reluctancy of my opinions. But if Mr. W. will be content to be the erratique, I shall be content to abate him the Heretique, in the bargaine, though I might very lawfully demand it.

But first let me aske Mr. W. (for I confesse I am to seeke and altogether ignorant in this poynt, if all that hee seemes to imply, be Gospell) what if it should bee granted, that both Arminius and Socinuss, were of the same judgement with me, in the interpretation of the Scriptures in Question? Is it either heresie or blasphemy,
yea or a simple errour, to professe or hold any thing that Heretiques or blasphemers have professed before? Then certainely it is both Arch-heresie and blasphemy to hold that Iesus Christ is the Sonne of God, because the Arch-blasphemer the Divell once professed it▪ and yet (it is like) beleeveth it, Mar. 1. 24. And if Mr. W. were but set upon this horse back himselfe, and made to ride as far as he would carry him, he would be the monster of all Hereticks before he return'd back again. He wo • ld be Socinian, Arminian, Servetian, Swenkfeldian, Osiandrian, Antitrinitarian, Arrian, Eutychian, Nestorian, Valentinian, Novatian, Pelagian, Donatist, Maniche, and what not? Because it is certaine that he holds some opinion in Religion, which all and every one of these held, as the unity of the Godhead, and many others. But it may be Mr. W. knowes how to distinguish here, as acutely betweene himselfe and his adversary, as some of our S • raphicall Doctors of Rome doe, when they tell us that the Scriptures, as they are alledged and cited by them, are the word of God: but as they are cited by us, they are the word of the Divel: so that the rule or ground of reason, which applyed to Mr. G. will make him a Heretick and blasphemer, being applyed to Mr. W. upon the same termes, is presently charmed, and looseth all its vertue and operation, and leaves him as Orthodox, as Saint Iohn himselfe.

Secondly, let me say this likewise, that it is but a knack of Papish Mountebankerie, to seeke to oppresse an opinion that any way crosseth them, and to derive envie and reproach upon the head of it, by putting it into evill company, and numbring it amongst the tenets and opinions of such men, as are otherwise obnoxious, and branded with the shame and infamy of some broad errour. Thus Prateolus (a Popish Author) makes account he strikes a great stroke against those, that hold it lawfull to eat any meates upon any day without making a difference, by finding this opinion held by Jovinian
an Heretique. So the same Author thinkes he doth the Romish cause Knights service against that opinion, which teacheth iustification by faith alone, by saying that this opinion was taught by Simon Magus. So to administer the Sacrament in both kinds, hee proves to be damnable, because Nestorius the Heretique did so. So againe he makes it one of the heresies of the Armeni, that they denyed Purgatory. This is a knowne trick of legerdemaine amongst them. Whatsoever my Adversary is in his opinion against me, Protestant, or Popish: certaine I am, that hee is purely, putely, and putidly Popish in the method of his proceedings against mee: and goes about to make the world beleeve, that my opinion must needs be an errour, yea and more then an errour, a damnable heresie, because forsooth (if men be so wise as to beleeve him) he brings newes from a far, and tells a tale, that he hath seene it amongst Socinian, and Arminian Heresies. A man that had look'd into the Lyons denne, whilst Daniel was there, might by as strong an Argument, have proved the Prophet to have beene a Beast: Mr. Wa. himselfe, if this tackling will hold, may prove Solomons Lilie, Cant. 1. 2. to be a thorne. Yea by the out-stretched arme of this Logick▪ the Iewes may justifie their crucifying of the Lord Christ, because hee was numbred amongst the transgressours, and two Malefactours crucified with him: which rare peice of profound policy, Mr. Wal. (it seemes) hath coppied out in his answere, in crucifying the truth betweene those two Malefactors, Socinus and Arminius. If Mr. W. had first proved the opinion maintained by mee to be erroneous, (but that is a worse Crow to pull, then any hee hath pluckt yet) and then have justly charged those sore aggravations of Arminianisme and Socinianisme upon it, it had been somewhat reasonable and methodicall: but to scourge it uncondemned (at least upon any lawfull triall and conviction) with the Scorpions of those odious imputations, shewes rather the canker in his pen, then
love either of truth, or men in his affections.

But thirdly, (and lastly) if either man or woman, be troubled in mind, upon this point, whether Mr. W. makes conscience or no, of what hee writeth, let him but diligently weigh and compare a few pages following, with the greatest part of his discourse, (wherein he speaks so much of Arminius and Socinus, and he shall receive satisfaction to his hearts desire. Arminius in resp. ad 4. Artic. impositum, saith, justitiam Christi nobis imputari, & fieri nostram gratiosâ aestimatione Dei, & arbitrari se, id ipsum contineri verbis Apostoli, 2 Cor. 5. Christum fecit Deus pro nobis peccatum, ut nos essemus justitia Dei in illo, that is, that the righteousnes of Christ is imputed to us, and is made ours by the gracious esteeme or account of God, and this hee conceives to be conteyned, in those words of the Apostle, 2 Cor. 5. God made Christ sinne for us, that we might be made the righteousnes of God in him.
div.q: Fortis ubi est Ajax? ubi sunt ingentia magni—Verba viri?
div.p: Where is brave Ajax? where the blustering brags of the sterne Champion? what Mr. Walker, tute Lepus es, & pulpamentum quaeris? Are you a Hare your selfe, and call for hare to eat? Is Mr. Walker himselfe an Arminian, and will crie out of Arminianisme.
div.q: Quis tulerit Gracchos de seditione querentes?

q.l: Who can indure to heare without disdaine,
The Gracchi of sedition to complaine?

div.p:
Or if he will disclaime Arminius judgement in the Testimony cited, touching the Imputation of Christs righteousnes, let him disclaime his own also. For sure no two judgements ever jump'd better together, then the judgement of Arminius the Heretique, and of Mr. W. the Orthodox in the point of Imputation. Therefore there is
a necessity lying upon him, either to take me into Communion, and fellowship with himselfe in his opinion about imputation, or else to deliver me from the imputation of Arminianisme, in what I hold.

I deny not, but Arminius himselfe (and some of his followers much more) expresse themselves (sometimes) on the other hand, and doe affirme, the imputation of Faith for righteousnes, and not the righteousnes of Christ, (in this uncertainty of expressing themselves,) resembling both Mr. W. himselfe, yea and men of farre greater note in the Church of Christ, whose names for the honour due unto them, upon this occasion I forbeare. But yet Mr. W. undertaking the office of an Interpreter of their mindes, and meanings this way, (though otherwise, I easily beleeve, no great friend of theirs) to make his charge against me, and my opinion the more heavy, and sore (as he hopes) hath in many things much eased and lightned their burdens, in the erroneous grossenes of their opinion, by his Interpretation. Before I demonstrate this, I would first know, by what prerogative Law, Mr. VV. should bee exempted or excused from being an Arminian, holding and maintaining directly, what Arminius himselfe in one place affirmeth: but I at no hand must be excused, holding what the same person affirmeth in another. I know not who hath given Mr. VV. any power to umpire betweene himselfe and me upon termes of such inequality. And further I desire to be Mr. Ws. Remembrancer of another thing by the way: That those are called false witnesses by the Holy Ghost, that gave Testimony against Christ, though they testifie little (in words) against him, but what himselfe indeed spake (Mat. 26. 60. 61) Their drawing and wresting his wordes besides his meaning, was enough to brand them, with that black brand. So though Mr. W. could (haply) pick out here and there, some phrases or expressions out of Arminius and his followers: that may in the letter and sound of wordes,
come neere some expressions used by mee, in setting downe my opinion: yet if upon this, hee will stand up, and beare witnesse against me, or my opinion, that we are Arminian: this will not save him harmelesse, against the just imputation of false witnesse-bearing. And as Anti-Arminian as himselfe is, or desires to appeare, it were an easie matter to reconcile him, if Similitude or Sympathie in speaking, now and then, would doe it. The saying of Bellarmine in this case, is sound and good: Non in verbis, sed in sensu, fides est, nec idem Symbolum habemus si in explicatione dissidemus. The greatest Hereticks of old, agreed with the Orthodox Fathers, in receiving the same Creed: yet were they of a farre different Faith, and judgement from them, in those Articles of Religion contained in the Creed. Now concerning my Antagonist, the truth is, that as he hath banished my minde and meaning out of my wordes (in many places) and put his own sowre, and distorted apprehensions in their stead, and would faine make me father the bastard-brood of his distempered imagination: So on the other hand, in laying downe the Arminian opinion touching those Scripture passages in Question, and the point of imputation, though he substitutes also, and rather gives them an opinion, then relates any from them, yet hee playes the part of a good fairy with them, and leaves them a changeling better favour'd then their owne child. But hee had no other way or method to bring both ends of his project together, to make the Arminian tenet and mine meet, but onely by taking their crooked opinion in his right hand, and my straight opinion in his left; and so bow the one, and unbow the other, till they should run parallell together.

To make good (in few wordes) what I say, concerning his favourable (but false) interpretation of the Arminian notion (in the things in question,) I desire that these two clauses following, wherein he represents (as he pretends) the opinion of Arminians, touching the
imputation of faith, may be diligently compared, with the interpretations and explications made of the same opinion, by other learned, godly, judicious and Orthodox Divines▪ that doubtles have as deepe an insight into those mysteries, and know what Spirit of errour it is that ruleth in the Kingdome of Remonstrancy, as well as Mr. Wal. doth: And more particularly, to those that desire fully to know, with how little dexterity or integrity, Mr VV. hath here deciphered the Arminian Doctrine (touching matters in Question) I desire to recommend the diligent perusall, of the tenth Chapter, of a Booke set forth by the foure famous Professours of Divinity (who lived amongst the ablest men of judgement, and where Arminianisme had it's Throne: and in this respect, were more likely to know their depths, then other men that are more strangers to them, about the year 1626, entitled, Censura in confessionem seu declarationem sententiae eorum, qui in foederato Belgio Remonstrantes vocantur &c.

The two passages in Mr VV. are these. First, that faith and beleeving, is the onely thing which God of his grace is pleased to ordaine, for all the righteousnes, which a man shall have for his justification &c. Secondly, by Faith and beleeving they understand no more but a confidence in God, that he will performe his promises made in Christ, and an assent unto his word, that it is true. Now he that shall compare these expressions (with others more in Mr VVs. wooddy explication) which pretend to shew what the Arminians meane by their faith, which they say is imputed for righteousnes, with severall expressions of their owne, cited by the forenamed Divines, and charged home with foulenesse: and dangerousnes of errour, will find them to agree like Harp and harrow. It fully appeares from severall passages there, that by that Faith, which the Arminians so generally affirme to bee imputed for righteousnes, they meane not a bare assent to the word of God, that it is true (which is Mr. VVs.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , but an universall obedience to the
will of God, in all those duties, which hee requires of men in the Gospell. In the beginning of that Chapter, they are challenged by these worthy Divines, for affirming the word, Faith, to be sometimes taken (in Scripture) protota & universâ illâ Dei voluntate that is, for the whole universall will of God, which b • fore they had said, God would have performed by us. In which sence, they would be taken and understood in this Chapter. Afterwards they are charged againe, with Pontifician friendship, in eo, quòd opera inter justificationis causas numerant, aequali cum fide iure, that is, that they place workes amongst the causes of iustification, and that with as much right, as Faith it selfe. Againe (a little after) they are charged to have drawne this their notion of faith in iustification, out of the Socinian Lakes, which yeeld such waters as these: Meminisse debemus, fidem hanc, Scilicetquà iustificamur, Dei obedientiam esse. That is, we must remember, that that Faith whereby wee are iustified, is the obeying of God. And presently after: In Christum credere nihil aliud est, quàm Deo ad ipsius Christi normam & praescriptum obedientem sepraebere. That is, To beleeve in Christ is nothing else, but for a man to yeild up himselfe in obedience to God according to the rule and prescript of Christ. To passe by many other passages in this chapter, to the same effect: The Arminian Doctrine is further charged, by that faith, which it holds to be imputed for righteousnes, to understand and meane, fidem ipsam in se, quae apud Deum habeatur pro iustitiâ, quatenus fidei nomine comprehenditur poenitentia, resipiscentia, & in universum obedientia hominis Christiani. So that either Mr. VValker, or these men are fouly out, in drawing the lineaments of the Arminian faith in this point of imputation. If Mr. W. will chuse rather to lay the burden upon their shoulder, I suppose it will not much pinch them, because I doe not thinke there is any man else will doe it but himselfe. I acknowledge there are some expressions, used by these great and learned
men▪ in this tract of their discourse, wherein I desire Christian leave to dissent from them: but as well for their ability as integrity, in representing the true, genuine, and native shape both of the Arminian and Socinian Doctrine in these points, I thinke their Authority is unparellable. Consonant unto these things, set downe by them, touching the way of Remonstrancy in the point under question, are those briefe passages that are found in Doctor Prideaux (a great light of the Church, yet living and shining) Lect. 5. de Iustificatione. Having mentioned Vorstius opinion, who held faith to bee imputed, immediatè & formaliter; meritum Christi, mediatè & effectivè, he addes as followeth: ubi per fidem ulteriùs ostendit, se observationem Christianismi solummodò intelligere, quia credere idem est, quod observare Christi praecepta, that is, by faith, he further sheweth, that he onely meaneth the observation of Christianity, because to beleeve, and to observe the Commandements of Christ, are the same. Nec dispuduit tandem concludere &c. that is. And was not asham'd at the last to conclude, that iustifying faith is that same inherent righteousnes, which the Papists urge▪ a little before, mentioning the opinion of Arminius himselfe, touching faith in the matter of iustification (as Corvinus a great Disciple of his undertakes to interpret his Master) Arminio (saith he) minimè placuit quod fides dicitur instrumentalis iustificationis nostrae causa, that is, Arminius would by no means have faith termed the instrumentall cause of iustification; which is as directly contrary to what I have openly professed, and maintained since my first dealing in this controversie, as it is to what Mr. VV. affirmeth, concerning the Arminians themselves, p. 4. Where he affirmeth, that they say that faith is imputed for righteousnes, as an instrument, which abundantly confirmes that which I said before, that Master VV. hath highly befriended the Arminian party in laying downe their opinion, onely to doe me and my opinion the great displeasure
and despite. The last named Doctor in the same Lecture, cites one thing more out of Bertius, (another Prince of the Arminian band) in an Epistle written by him to Lubbertus: viz. that here hee acknowledgeth, hanc sententiam meritum Christ • excludere, that is, that the opinion of Vorstius touching the imputation of his Faith (which is the same with the common opinion of the Remonstrants, as was before intimated) doth exclude the merit of Christ, (viz. from justification) which againe is not more contrary, to what Mr. W. grants concerning the Arminians, viz. that they acknowledge Christs perfect satisfaction and righteousnes, to be the meritorious cause of our iustifications p. 4. then to what I have both publiquely taught ever since my first stepping into these waters of strife, (as some have made them) still ready to professe and maintaine (upon occasion) every houre. I wish that Master VV. and his opinion, maintaining the imputation of the active obedience of Christ (in the letter and formality of it) for righteousnes, did no more endanger or trench upon the merit of Christs satisfaction, then either I or mine opinion do. I doe not charge any guiltinesse that way upon the man: I verily conceive of him, that it is farre from his intentions, either to deny or to destroy, or in the least measure to wrong or prejudice the satisfaction of Christ: but for that opinion of his concerning imputation, it hath beene arrested and arraigned elsewhere, and was found full, if not of perfect guilt, yet of much jealousie and suspicion that way. There are severall other things in this tract of his discourse, concerning the corrupt exposition of Socinus, Arminius &c. as one or two contradictions, with some such pettie oversights, and diverse things affirmed loosely and at peradventure, without the least proofe or semblance of truth, which if matters of exception and advantage, were any thing rare and hard to come by, might be improved to good purpose that way. But I rest contented with this onely,
to make it knowne to the VVorld, that Master Ws. Arminianisme, and Arminianisme indeed, are in many things (and those of mainest importance in the question depending) as contrary the one to the other, as the East is to the West: and that the opinion maintained by me, in the notes I left with him, hath as little of Arminian blood running in the veynes of it, as the opinion that himselfe maintaineth, yea and farre lesse too, if matters were throughly sifted and examined betweene us. The Arminian Faith, which they set up for imputation unto righteousnes, includes obedience to the Law of God Mr. Walkers Faith, set up by him for the same purpose, includes obedience to the same Law: their faith an obedience performed in their owne person: Mr. Ws. Faith or obedience, as if it had beene performed in their owne persons. The Arminian faith excludes (as we have heard) the merit of Christs satisfaction from iustification: and Mr. Ws. faith if it were well examined, doth little lesse. For he that hath a perfect legall righteousnes imputed unto him upon as good termes, as if he had performed it in his owne person, what need hath he of any satisfaction, or attonement by blood, to bee made for him? But I have impleaded this opinion, more at large else where, and have wrung the best weapons out of the hand of the adversary, wherein he most puts his trust. I shall therefore here rest from this labour. And for Mr. Ws. Arminianisme, how oft soever he shall afterwards bee troublesome to mee, therewith in his discourse, I shall neither be troublesome to my selfe, nor to my Reader with it any more; but let it goe for naught, when it comes in my way. Onely this I will say for it, before I here give it over, that so wee may yet have a friendly parting: that if ever I be weary of the truth and desire to turne Arminian, I will be an Arminian of of Mr. Ws. calculation: his Arminian, is incomparably better, and more harmelesse in his dogmaticalls, then any other mans Arminian that I can meet with. And
notwithstanding his Charity hath abounded towards the Arminian party (as you have heard) yet towards the Socinian, it abounds much more. Other Divines and Writers generally, represent Socinianisme upon the Stage, as an accursed Denier of Christs satisfaction. Sociniani (saith Doctor Prideaux in his fifth Lecture de iustificatione) impudentius negant, Christum pro peccatis nostris satisfecisse: & ubivis asserunt &c. that is: The Socinians more impudently deny, that Christ made any satisfaction for our sinnes, and still affirme, that God the Father hath received us into grace or favour, by a free condonation or remission of sinnes, for Christ. But Mr. W. making them to draw in the same yoke with his Arminians, wipes off this foule aspersion from them, and claps on a beutie's spot (in comparison) upon their face, in stead of it: speaking of them both together thus: when they acknowledge that Christ his perfect satisfaction and righteousnes, is the meritorious cause of our iustification &c. So that it seemes Mr. W. hath wrought a great and miraculous cure upon the Socinian heresie, and hath brought it back ten degrees (at least) by which it was gone downe towards Hell: It now acknowledgeth Christs perfect satisfaction, as the meritorious cause of our iustification: onely it halts upon a lame interpretation, of what it holds consonant to the truth. But Mr. W. (I conceive) was more provident and subtile then angrie men usually are, in displaying the Socinian heresie by the figure Synechdoche, onely mentioning a part (and that a very small one too) for the whole: for by this meanes he gaines more liberty▪ and freedome, to draw me and my opinion into the reproach, and scandall thereof. For otherwise had hee but mentioned that which is the head and height of Socinian blasphemy, viz. the denying the merit and satisfaction of Christ, now it would not have so much as coloured with the opinion maintained by me, which riseth up with a high hand to plead the merit of that satisfaction. But
Mr. VV. having onely a desire and intent to cast dirt in the face of the truth, and him that maintaines it, was loath to loose the opportunity of such a kennell. Otherwise as Martial descanted upon the Painter, that had drawne a picture of Venus somewhat coursely, and untowardly, saying of him, that surely he meant to flatter Minerva,

So on the contrary, a man might thinke, that Mr. Ws. intent in drawing the portraitures of the Arminian and Socinian heresies, with so much favour, was onely to oppresse the ancient heresies, of Arrius and the rest, with new envie and indignation.

Well: Master W. having so fouly and Ignoramus-like miscarried in acquainting us with the state of the Arminian and Socinian heresie in the exposition of his Scriptures, and having painted the Crow and Raven, more like a Dove, and a Partridge then otherwise: I appeale to Master Ws. owne conscience, (if there be any motion or life yet left in it) whether here be not a fitter and more just occasion, then any hee hath met with in my writing (if a man had a mind to it) to cry out, lyar, lying Sophister, ignorant, impudent, &c. And yet I confesse againe, that though I had a mind to doe it, it were no wisedome (but impudent foolishnes indeed) to write the destruction of Troy after Homer. But if Mr. W. bee no better, at giving us out the mind of the Holy Ghost in the Scriptures, then hee hath shewed himselfe an Interpreter of the mysteries of the Arminian, and Socinian heresie, (and it is much to be feared the whole piece is of the same spinning) instead of the true and Orthodox exposition of the Apostles meaning, you shall have the Heterodox and mishapen conceipt of his owne brain, set up upon the Stage before you. I will spend no
more time about Master VVs. Socinianisme, neither (though it be the best that ever man met with, or can hope to meet with in any Author under Heaven) except, it be to say this: though he professeth the deepest enmity and even a hellish detestation of that way, yet is he the greatest Tempter and allurer of men into this way, of any I know, one or other, at this day living amongst us, by his too too ingenuous and gracious qualification of their blasphemous errours.

The true exposition defended, here my Antagonist, beingMr. VV. p. 5, 6, 7, &c. conscious (it seemes) that hee had not played the man, in laying downe the sence and meaning of the Scriptures in question, before (page 1. and 2.) sufficiently, hopes to come into his credit (in due time) by bestowing words enough upon the businesse, if his Reader will be content to take that for payment. If hee will not, I know not how he will much mend himself by this long word discourse of severall pages together. I professe ingenuously, I never met with more loose, indigested, and male-coherent stuffe from the pen of a Scholar, within such a compasse, all my dayes. I dare not say that Mr. W. himselfe wants either Logique or Rhetorique: but this I may boldly say, that many things that come from him, are like to starve through extreme want of both: There is scarce ever a page but enterfires with other: Neither is there any thing said to purpose in one place, but is unsaid in another: his notions and sayings, being like unto Cadmus his souldiers that sprang up of the Dragons teeth.

q.hi: Marte cadunt proprio per mutua vulnera fratres. • .

div.q: Brother his Brother Wounds to death each other.
div.p:
So that Mr. W. needs not send to me to answere this piece of his: he hath performed the service himselfe to himselfe, and plainly sheweth, that hee objecteth nothing against me, but what hee knoweth himself how to answere. And if he will seale to • , and ratifie what with
open mouth he affirmeth, in this limb of his discourse, he will ipso facto cancell and deface the whole body besides. For doth he not (after an importune and impertinent discourse, concerning the difference betweene that Faith, which he calls a naturall habit or power, and that which he defines a supernaturall guift &c.) come to grant (page 7.) that Abraham resting upon the Lord by firme Faith, for the performance of the promises made to him, the Lord counted it to him for righteousnes, and presently after (somewhat more emphatically, and with better agreement to the truth, then to his owne opinion) even Faith was reckoned to him for righteousnes. And more plainely afterwards page 11. where he pretends to center the large circumference of his former discourse thus: By faith and beleeving, which is counted to every true beleever, (and was counted to Abraham) for righteousnes I understand here (according to the iudgement of the most Orthodox Divines,) the true, holy, spirituall Faith and beleef, which is before shewed to have beene in Abraham, and which is proper to the elect and regenerate &c. Now whether such a faith as this, being as himselfe acknowledgeth, that very faith, which he had so operously and carefully distinguished, defined, explaned, page 7. 8. be a tropicall or Metonymicall faith, or Faith in the proper nature, and direct signification, I leave to those that want that, wherewith Master W. so aboundeth, to judge and to consider. Therefore if he meanes as hee saith in this place, that faith in the proper sence, and not in the figurative (in which sence, according to his acute interpretation, it signifieth th •
righteousnes of Christ, apprehended by it) be that which is imputed unto a beleever for righteousnes, what have we to doe with all the discourse following?
div.q: Aut fugiat Vticam, aut unctus mittatur Ilerdam.

q.l: Downe let it swimme the streame to Vtica,
Or to Ilerda nointed let it passe.

div.p: Let him disband those troopes of slanders, reproches, calumnies, falsifications, which hee hath mustered up against mee in the sequell of his Tract, for holding and maintaining the same interpretation of the word faith, which himself here avoucheth▪ And further that by faith in these Scriptures, which is oft said to bee imputed for righteousnes, Master W. cannot understand a tropicall or Metonymicall Faith, viz. the righteousnes of Christ, is as evident, as the foulest non-sence is from the fairest truth: because immediately after page 11. interpreting the word righteousnes, he saith by it is meant the righteousnes of Christ &c. So that if by faith we shall understand, the righteousnes of Christ, and by righteousnes, the righteousnes of Christ too, we must make the Apostles meaning, in plaine language to run thus: the righteousnes of Christ, is imputed to a beleever, for the righteousnes of Christ: which is such a Hyper absurdity, that in Honour to Mr. Ws. intellectualls and learning, I cannot fasten upon him. Therefore whatsoever he talks afterward in his discourse, of a tropicall and metonymicall acception of Faith in these Scriptures, I will not beleeve but that he is in jest there, and in earnest here. I doe not thinke so m • anely of him, that he will cast away his gold, to fill his hand with chaff in stead of it.

But the truth is, that in all he hath done (infolio) about the explication of this Scripture, hee hath onely prospered, in his interpretation of the word, Faith, or beleeving: which prosperity notwithstanding stayeth him, in all (almost) that followeth: and is it not pitty that faire weather should doe harme? In his exposition of the two other words, imputing and righteousnesse he boggles and slunders fouly.

First, for the phrase of imputing a thing to one, hee makes a supposition, that to impute and accompt, or count, are universally termini aequipollentes, wordes alwayes of one and the same signification. Against which misp • rision his owne instances from the Scriptures, might
have releived him. For 1 King. 1. 21. Where Bathsheba saith to David, I and my Sonne Solomon shall be counted offendors, it had hardly beene good English to have said, I and my Sonne Solomon shall be imputed offendors. So Nehe. 13. 13. where it is said of the Levites, that they were counted faithfull, it would have come off somewhat rugged, to have said, that they were imputed faithfull. In some cases, and falls of speech, I confesse they may be of indifferent use, and signification, and particularly in the Scriptures in hand: to say that Abrahams Faith, either was counted, or imputed to him for righteousnes, are both expressions of good propriety; and not much difference betweene them (except a man hath a mind to cavill and wrangle.) And wherein Master W. hath strengthned his cause, by making these two terms, imputing and counting, to run alwayes hand in hand, I doe not yet apprehend: except it bee by gaining an opportunity of laying on more tongue, and multiplying discourse: which how it availeth him in this businesse, hath bin already intimated.

But the man is no where liker himselfe (as touching the whole cariage of this businesse) then in the description he layes downe, of the sence or signification of the phrase, imputing a thing to one, page 9. His description is this: the phrase of imputing or counting a thing to one, signifieth both in the Old and New Testament, an act of judgement and estimation, by which a thing is judged, esteemed, reckoned, and accounted, to bee as it is indeed. Capiat, qui potis est capere. Let him understand it, that hath where withall. I confesse Master Ws. eloquence passeth my intelligence. But

First, I should have thought (had I not beene here informed otherwise, and may yet for ought I know, strayne curtesie with my information) that God his imputing faith for righteousnes (take faith in what sence you will) had bin an act of grace or mercy in God, and not an act of judgement.

Secondly, every act of judging or esteeming a thing, to be as indeed it is, is not an imputing or counting it to another: which yet must bee, if Master W. hath rightly defined or described the signification and importance of the phrase of imputing: because the old standing Law of a true definition is, that it must be convertible with that which is defined. But that every iudging or esteeming a thing, to be as indeed it is, is no imputing it to another, is evident: because when I judge the Sun to be greater then the Moone, I judge it as indeed it is: yet doe I not impute the Sunne to any man. So when I judge and esteeme Master Ws. quarrell against mee, to be groundlesse and causelesse, I iudge and esteeme the thing, as indeed it is: yet doe I not hereby impute it to any man.

Thirdly, when God imputes either my Faith unto me, or Christs righteousnes unto me (the one being the Scripture phrase, the other Mr. VValkers,) for my righteousnes he doth not iudge, or esteeme any thing to bee as indeed it is: for neither is my faith, nor the righteousnes of Christ indeed my righteousnes. But my faith in Christ, is that Grace which God hath consecrated, and ordained to bring me into Communion and fellowship of that righteousnes, that is, of that iustification and redemption which Christ by the merit of his life and death hath purchased for me, and for all those that beleeve in him. Therefore the phrase of imputing doth not signifie, an act of judgement or estimation, by which a man iudgeth or esteemeth a thing to be as indeed it is.

Fourthly, neither doe any of the instances from Scripture, either of the Old or New Testament, which himselfe produceth, any thing willingly, or naturally comply with this his description, of the signification of the word, imputing, as will appeare to any man, that shall but considerately and unpartially umpire betweene them.

Fif • ly▪ (and lastly) there are some of these instances,
