that doe manifestly contradict that description of his, and that according to his owne interpretation, of the phrase imputing, when he comes to cite them. As that 2. Sam. 19. 19. where Shimei saith, Let not my Lord impute iniquity unto mee. He doth not (saith Mr. VV. and that very truely, but contradictingly to himselfe) desire that David would not thinke, nor judge, nor count his iniquitie to be no iniquitie: this had beene against all reason. Therefore (say I) it is against all reason too, that Mr. W. should say that the phrase of imputing both in the Old and New Testament, still signifies an act of judgement and estimation, by which a thing is judged and esteemed, to bee as it is indeed. Shimei's act in cursing David, was iniquitie: and yet Shimei desireth (neither doth he herein desire any thing sinfull or unlawfull on Davids part to grant) that it might not be imputed, as, or for iniquity unto him. So when Iob pleading with God. Iob 33. 10. saith that God counted him for his enemy: he doth not charge God foolishly▪ or affirme any thing unworthy of him: and yet Iob was not Gods enemy, though it be here said, that God counted him so, or, for such. Therefore the phrase of counting or imputing, even when it is applyed to God himselfe, doth not alwayes signifie such an act of judgement or estimation, as Mr. W. describeth.

So in the New Testament, where it is said Rom. 2. 26. that the uncircumcision (viz. of the Heathen keeping the Law) shall be counted for circumcision, it is meant of God himselfe, that it shall be so counted by him. Yet no man I conceive, (except perhaps Mr. W.) will say, that uncircumcision, is circumcision indeed. Where God is said; not to impute sinne (viz▪ to persons beleeving, and consequently justified) as Rom. 4. 8. 2 Cor. 5. 19. the meaning is not, that God doth not judge or esteeme a beleever to have sinne in him (which were an act of judgement or estimation, whereby the thing were judged
• o be, as it is indeed:) but by Gods not imputing sinne, is
meant Gods gracious absolving, or discharging such men from guilt, and punishment due unto sinne. Therefore to impute sinne to a man (in Scripture phrase) and so to impute righteousnes▪ signifies an act of a farre differing nature a • d importance, from that which Mr. W. layes downe, viz an act of iudgement, and whereby a man judgeth and esteemeth a thing to be, as indeed it is. God iudgeth or esteemeth (by an act of knowledge or understanding) every thing to bee, as it is indeed: and yet he counteth one thing for another, which it is not indeed (as you have heard) and so he imputeth one thing for another, which it is not indeed. Take Mr. Ws. one tenet or supposition: the truth hereof will appeare no where more evident then in that. God (saith Mr. W.) imputeth the righteousnes of Christ unto us, for our righteousnes, that is, for that righteousnes which we should have performed in our persons. And yet who will affirme (except the before excepted) that the personall righteousnes of Christ is the righteousnes indeed, which wee should have performed in our owne persons? It may be a righteousnesse of the same natu • e and kind: and yet be farre from being the same righteousnes indeed, which requires all the same individuating circumstances, as of time, person, number and nature of acts &c. Therefore how importune is Mr. W. in bringing in that Epiphonêma here, Gods thoughts are alwayes iust, and his iudgement according to truth, as if Gods imputing righteousnes to him that is a sinner, and hath no righteousnes, were an act of iniustice in him, and contrary to truth: or as if he had to doe with one, that denyed either directly or indirectly, either expressely or by consequence, the one or the other. Gualter, an Orthodox and learned Interpreter, findes grace and favour, not strictnesse of iudgement, in the phrase of imputation. Docet imputandi verbum (saith he in his 20. Homily upon the Romans) posse Deum suo erga nos iure uti, gratiae verò eius hoc nos debere, quòd aliter nobiscum agit, quàm nos me
• uimus, that is, the phrase of imputation teacheth us,
that God might indeed have dealt in strictnesse of iudgement with us, and that we are indebted to his free grace, that he dealeth not with us as wee have deserved. But concerning the signification or importance of the word, or phrase imputing, (in the busines of iustification) more afterwards. In the meane time let us examine Mr. Ws. dexterity, in explaining the third word, Righteousnes: Surely we shall find him no where more left-handed then here. If I knew where his Logick or Rhetorick were, they deserv'd a chiding, to give no better attendance upon their Master, where he had such occasion to have used them. But in their absence, this is the best explication of the word, righteousnes, he can afford us. By righteousnes (saith he) is here meant Euangelicall righteousnes (which is opposed to the legall righteousnes of works, which is inherent in every man, and is every mans fulfilling the Law in his own person) even the perfect satisfaction and righteousnes of Christ, our Mediatour and surety, which hee the Sonne of God, in mans nature performed to the Law, &c. p. 11. Riddle mee, riddle me, what's this? For

First can Faith in any sence, proper, tropicall, Metonymicall (let beggers themselves be chusers here) be said to be imputed to us for the satisfaction, or righteousnes of Christ? I thought Mr. Ws. opinion had bin, that this satisfaction or righteousnes of Christ, had beene imputed to us for some other thing, but no other thing imputed for it. And indeed what (in reason) can bee conceived should be imputed unto us, for▪ or instead of the satisfaction of Christ? especially according to Mr. Ws. notion of imputation, wherein it is required, that the thing imputed, be truely, really, and indeed the same, with that for which it is imputed. Surely there is nothing truely really & indeed the same with the satisfaction of Christ, but this satisfaction it self. And whether any thing may properly be said, to be truly & indeed the same with it self, I refer to Mr. Ws. owne determination, when his Logique returnes againe to him. However, if by righteousnes (in this
place) he will needs understand the righteousnes of Christ, here is a relapse into his former acute interpretation, and makes the current of the place this: Faith that is, the righteousnes of Christ, is imputed to us for righteousnes, that is, for the righteousnes of Christ.
div.q: Hic furor haud dubius: haec est manifesta phrenesis.
div.p: Secondly why he should call the righteousnes of Christ, an Euangelicall righteousnes, and that with such emphaticall opposition to the legall, and yet define a legall righteousnes to be, every mans fulfilling of the Law in his owne person, I want Mr. Ws. intellect to comprehend. Surely Christs righteousnes was a fulfilling of the Law in his owne person: I doe not know (nor I thinke Mr. VV. himselfe, though he knowes so much more then I doe) any other man that perform'd it for him, yea himselfe (in the close of this period) acknowledgeth it to have beene performed by himselfe unto the Law.

Thirdly, whereas he affirmes a legall righteousnes of workes to be inherent in every mans person, it may bee he consulted with his own Logick about his expression: but surely other mens never advised him so to speake. Workes or actions are matters transient, not inherent.

Fourthly, why he should say that to be inherent in every man, which was never inherent in any man, (no not in his owne sence of inherency) Christ onely excepted, I beleeve it would a little trouble him, to give a faire accompt.

Fiftly, why he should affirme the Euangelicall righteousnes of Christ to be a satisfaction performed to the Law, i • himselfe can give no better reason then I can, it must either passe by authority, and by vertue of the writ, Ipse dixit, or else be arrested and staied. For though the active obedience or righteousnes of Christ, may be called a satisfaction to the Law, in as much as the Law requires such obedience from all men: and that properly is a satisfaction
either to a person or thing, when the whole is given, that is required or demanded. But how the death or passive obedience of Christ (which I conceive Mr. W. chiefly intendeth, in the word satisfaction) should bee a satisfaction performed to the Law, it will take more of my thoughts to apprehend, then yet I have leysure to bestow upon it. The Law was satisfied in that perfect and intire obedience, which Christ exhibited to it, from the beginning of his life to the end: and did not require of him (no more then it doth of any other man that shall fulfill it, as hee did) that he should be made a curse, or dye the death. If Mr. Ws. meaning bee, that the death of Christ was a satisfaction performed to the Law for us, or on our behalfe, in respect of our sinnes: I answere that he doth not yet hit the joint: for this is no part of the demands of the Law, that an innocent or righteous person should dye, but onely the transgressors and disobedient. Therefore when a righteous person dieth, it is rather a crossing, then a satisfaction to the Law: because the Law promiseth life, to those that keep and fulfill it, & do • h no wayes threaten or impose death upon them. It is true, the death of Christ was satisfactory for the sinnes of the world; but to whom was it a satisfaction? not to the Law, which neither required, nor demanded it, nor yet had any power to release, or discharge her Prisoners, and condemned ones, upon the tender and payment of it: the Law knowes no satisfaction▪ But to God (the Law giver) who had a power over and beyond his Law, it was a satisfaction, because hee indeed required it, and to him it was tendred and performed.

Sixtly (and lastly) this Dedalian Divine, makes no clever worke, when he jumbles together the active, and passive, obedience of Christ, and sets the passive before the active, and subjecteth them to the same consideration, in respect of their performance to the Law. But his greater oversights are good for nothing, except it be to overshadow
his lesser, therefore it is pitty this priviledge should be denyed unto them.

I conceive by this time Mr Ws. owne heart smites him, and tel's him, that he hath not quitted himselfe in the opening of his Scriptures, answerably to the confidence reposed in him, by those that chose him for their Champion. Pauls imputation is yet a secret; notwithstanding, Mr Ws. interpretation hath passed upon it, yea, by tampering with a false key, he hath made the Lock harder to open then it was before. If any man or Woman, long's for contradictions, or other absurdities of the blood, I can yet relieve them out of this tract of Mr Ws. Answere before I leave it.

Pag. 6 he affirmeth, (and that truely as I conceive) Faith to be the first & radical grace and vertue of renovation: and yet pag 5. in his definition of faith, he supposeth the Subject or person in whom it is wrought, to be regenerate, (which is as much doubtlesse, as renewed) before. Againe, pag 9. he affirmeth, that God doth accompt and judge of all persons and things, so as they are, and yet pag 11. granteth, that God counted Iob his enemy, which he was not▪ Sop. 5. he defines, & affirmes that faith which is here sayd to be imputed for righteousnesse, to be the supernaturall guift and grace of beleeving: and yet pag 8. he saith, that God imputes a righteousnes which neither consists in any worke, or workes, nor in any grace, or vertue inherent. and pag. 12. by imputing faith for righteousnesse, he saith, is meant Gods setting of Christs righteousnesse on the skore, and putting it on the account of every true beleever, &c.
div.q: At{que} idem jungat vulpes, et mulgeat hircos.

q.l: This man can Foxes yoke in Plough,
And make wild Goates give Milk enough.

div.p:
But thus much for contradictions in this place; and I
thinke well too (all things considered.) Pag 7 and 8. Pretending to define that Faith, which the Apostle saith is imputed for righteousnesse: he defines a strong Faith, or Faith in the highest degree. So that if Mr Ws. Divinity were Gospel, woe to the weake-faith'd Christian, (how true soever his Faith should be) he must to Hell notwithstanding: such faith is not capable of Pauls imputation for righteousnesse: for pag 6. in laying downe the second difference (as he calls it) betweene the faith the Apostle meaneth, and the naturall habit or power of faith, he affirmeth, the Spirit of God, in working that faith, confirmes the heart with CONFIDENCE, AND FIRME PERSWASION; you shall find words of like importance in the very definition it selfe, which he gives of this faith pag 6. I will not be troublesome to him, in desiring him to shew his license, for making the 4 Kings slaughtered by Abraham, so mighty, p 7. Onely this I say, that in such his advancement of their puissance, and greatnes, he doth not Dogmatize with my Authors, nor with the common opinion, which makes the Kings of those times, in comparison of the Kings that now are on Earth, but as Grassehoppers, in respect of Gyants: nor (as far as I am able to apprehend) with the Scriptures themselves, which make five severall Kings of five Cities, which were Scituate no great distance the one from the other, and besides some of them, none of the largest, Gen. 14. 2. Lastly, pag 12. where he saith, that God sets Christ righteousnesse on the skore, and puts it on the accompt of every true beleever: I would gladly know, whether his meaning be, that God accounteth every beleever to have done and suffered, the things which Christ did and suffered, or what other tollerable construction or meaning can be fitted to those expressions. If God puts the righteousnesse it selfe, of Christ, upon a beleevers skore, he must put the merit of it also upon the same skore, for these are inseparable. If he puts the merit of Christs righteousnesse upon this skore, he must put all the fruites and effects of
this merit also; for these likewise are as inseparable as the other. And so God shall accompt every true believer to have redeemed, justified, and saved the world.
div.q: For the confirmation of this exposition, and justifyingM. VV. from p. 12▪ to 15. of this truth, &c.
div.p: Here the Answerer buckles on his harnesse, and meanes to fight stoutly for his beloved Dalila, the beautifull interpretation hitherto given by him, of the words in question: onely I desire you to remember, and to carry steadily, and distinctly in minde with you, what this interpretation was, that so you may the better discern and judg, how close the sute of his Arguments and proofes, sits upon the back of his interpretation to be proved. The Summe and effect of his interpretation (as you have heard) and if any thing can be made of it, this is) Faith aprehending Christ or the righteousnesse of Christ, is imputed to a beleever, for the Evangelicall righteousnesse of Christ. Now let us see how he laye's about him, and with what singular Dexterity, and learning, he proves twise fifteene, to make just three and twenty.

The first Argument (saith he) is drawne from the wordes of the Apostle, Rom. 2. 26. &c. He may well say, his Argument is drawne, and might have added, Obtorto collo, by head and shoulders: the man in forging this argument, labours (as it were) in the very fire, and though he gives it heat upon heat, yet he brings it to no shape or perfection at all, at the last, but is in the managing of it, as a wild Bull in a Net (which is the prophet Esay's comparison in another case) who beates and teares himselfe with strugling, but knowes not how to expedite or deliver himselfe ever the more. If a mans reason, wits, or understanding, had offended him, Mr. W. hath provided rods of Scorpions in the carriage of this Argument, to scourge them with. I might very lawfully excuse my selfe from saying any thing by way
of Answere to this Argument, by authority of that saying,
Quod non vult intelligi, debet negligi, that is,
Vnderstood what will not be,
To neglect you may be free.

Mr. W. himselfe I hope will (in part) excuse me, if I cannot find out the quadrature of his circle: I confesse I was never made for that speculation, neither take I any contentment to fish in such troubled waters? However, something must be done, Gamesters must play bad games and hard casts, as well as good.

The Scripture Mr. VV. so largely insist's upon, to prove his interpretation of the former, viz that faith (in a tropicall sense, that is, as it signifieth the righteousnesse of Christ) is imputed to a beleever, for the Evangelicall righteousnesse of Christ is this: Rom. 2. 26. If the uncircumcision keepe the righteousnesse of the Law, shall not his uncircumcision be counted for circumcision? Surely this Scripture, if it were well managed, would do good Service towards the pulling downe of the said Interpretation, but for the building of it up, it can do none at all, till it selfe be pulled downe; I meane the true sense and meaning of it destroyed, which Mr W. labours hard, and with both his hands to doe in this place; and yet when he hath done all, he hath (upon the matter) done nonothing. For if all the particulars were granted in the first and most liberall manner, for which he contendeth about the meaning of this Scripture, yet would they operate no more, then what might be summ'd up in a Cypher, towards the establishing of the other interpretation, (which is the thing intended by him) as will evidently appeare to a considering Reader. What if he could prove that here were trope, upon trope, and mountaines of metonymies; doth this prove a necessity of finding either the same number, or the same kind of
tropes or figures, in an other Scripture? And yet in this consequence, lieth the best part of the strength and sinewes of Mr. Ws. Argument from this place.

But let us make something of nothing, as well as we can, and give you a tast of his profound interpretation of this Scripture. By uncircumcision (saith he) in the former clause, we cannot understand the foreskin of the flesh &c. (but a Gentile not circumcised, &c.) By the same word in the latter clause, not the foreskin, or uncircumcision, in a proper sense &c. but the state and condition of him that is uncircumcised, and yet not this neither barely considered in it selfe, but as comprehending in it the righteousnesse of the Law, &c. And yet immediately he adds, that this word further in this very place, signifieth the man in the state of uncircumcision, keeping the righteousnesse of the Law, and yet this figuratively too, for the righteousnes of the Law, by him performed. I thinke we are in the Quagmires or quick-sands already, but let us goe forward, and we shall be sure to be in before we have done. By circumcision (saith further towards the opening of this Scripture) we cannot understand, the outward cutting away, of the foreskin of the flesh, &c. but by circumcision is here meant the circumcision of the heart, in the spirit. The word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 shall be counted, signifies (in a full sense) judging, counting, accepting, and using accordingly. Thus we have (with much adoe) spelled Mr. Ws. interpretation of this Scripture. Now let us put together, and see what we have gotten. If a Gentile not circumcised, keepe the Law, shall not his state and condition, not barely considered in it selfe, but as comprehending in it, the righteousnesse of the Law, that is, The man in the state of uncircumcision, keeping the righteousnes of the Law, that is, the righteousnes of the Law by him performed, be judged▪ accepted, and used accordingly, as the circumcision of the heart in the Spirit? This is the expresse tenor, and carriage of his exposition of this Scripture, conceived in his owne words, without
either adding any thing, or diminishing any thing, (to my knowledge) which should make matters any whit worse, or more exorbitant, from sense or reason, then as himselfe hath delivered them. Something I have left out, which would be as Oyle to encrease the fire, and would burden the interpretation further, as viz. where he brings up a false report upon Gods gracious intent, in giving the Sacrament, or Seale of circumcision, to the Jewes. It was (saith he) an obligation, by which the circumcised was bound under paine of cutting off forever, to performe the whole Law, and to prove this so irrationall, and extravagant a supposition, hee misuseth that Scripture, Gal. 5. 3. I testify to every man that is circumcised, that he is a debtor to doe the whole Law, which place doth not speake of any obligation upon men from God, to doe the whole Law, under paine of damnation, or cutting off for ever, for then miserable had the case and condition bin of the whole Nation of the Iewes, who generally, from the time when circumcision was first given by God, to their Father Abraham, were circumcised till now, and yet certainely none of them performed the whole Law, but failed or offended more or lesse, in many things (as Iames speaketh) and so by the cruel Sword of Mr. VVs. interpretation, must be all cut off from God for ever. But the Apostles meaning clearely in this Scripture is to shew, that if any man were circumcised in such a way, or with any such purpose or intent, as the Iewish teachers of circumcision amongst them urged, and pressed them unto: that is, with a conceipt of the necessitie thereof to justification; then were they in reason bound, as wel to observe all other points of the Law, as that of circumcision, there being no ground to hope they should be iustified, by the observation of one thing in the Law, if any other were neglected. For the rule of God in this case is, Cursed be he that continueth not in all things that are written in the Law, to doe them. This is Calvins exposition of this
place, or very little differing from it. But when men crie out against reason, as the Answerer in great passion doth, in the sequel of his discourse, they receive but a just recompence, of reward, to be delivered up into the hand of Non-sense. But let Non-sense say what it will, the man will not be dash'd out of countenance, by it, but wil need's set this Crown of fine Gold, upon the head of his Leaden interpretation, strike it off who dares, and makes him a Rebel, or Traytor, that shall rise up against it. This sense, and meaning, of the wordes and of this phrase, is so cleare, and manifest, and so perfectly agreeable to all true reason, that none can deny it, unlesse he will set himselfe to rebell against the light. I thought he would have lik'd his interpretation the worse, for being agreeable to any reason, and so would any other man thinke, that shall but read his invective. Pag 27. against that great enemie of his, which still thwarteth, and contradicteth him, in most of his undertakings▪ Right Reason. And it doth no lesse in this place, though here he would faine be friends, and scrape acquaintance with it.

But when he comes to parallell the Scripture last interpreted by him (as you have heard) and his interpretation thereof, with the Scriptures in question, and attempts a conformity betweene them in their interpretations, he falls into such a Rhetoricall rage and fury, and buffets his reader, so thick and so fast, with tropes, and figures, that it is not for a meane man to come neare his meaning (at least if his meaning be mans meat, any thing prepared for the understanding) by 40 foot. He had need have Angels for his readers, or men of Angelicall comprehensions, otherwise his tyrannicall and sterne Oratory, will be ready to laugh them in the face to scorne: Onely thus much, a man of low apprehensions, and that wants both Logique, and Rhetorique, (as Mr. W. lamentably complaines, pag 28. 29. that his adversary doth) may evidently perceive; that here with his left handed
Retorique, he quite pulls downe the good interpretation of the word Faith, or beleeving (in his Scripture) which he had formerly built up with his right-handed reason. For if you looke back to pag 6. there you shall find him with this description of that faith, or beleeving, which is here sayd to be imputed to Abraham for righteousnesse. Here by Faith we are to understand, that supernaturall guift, and grace of beleeving, wrought in the Elect by the Spirit, &c. Which whether it be a description, or definition of faith properly (yea, most properly) taken, I am not much afrayd to make the party himselfe Judge. Yet in this place page. 14. (heu regni, rerum{que} oblitus suarum,
alas forgetfull of his great affaires? he delivers (or rather indeed, intangles) himselfe thus. We must by Abrahams beleeving, by a metalepsis, or double trope, understand Abrahams standing in the state of a true beleever, united, &c. And presently after, By Faith imputed, or counted for righteousnes, we must not understand, faith in a proper sense, but by a double trope, for the estate and condition, of a true faithfull man &c.
div.q: Quo teneam vultus mutantem Portea nodo?

q.l: It's hard to know what knot to tye,
To make wild Porteus skill to lie.

div.p:
If Abrahams standing in the state of a true beleever, united, &c. be that supernaturall guift, and grace of beleeving, wrought in the Elect, by the Spirit, &c. (as Mr. VV. hath synonymizd them) Xanthe retro propera, &c. Let Xanthus backward run, and Rivers all turne head - upon their Fountaines—Yea, the m • n is so intemperate in contradictions, that in the very next page, towards the close he affirmeth, that which (ineffect) he had 7 times denyed before, viz. That the faith of that man which doth not rest on his owne workes for justification, as comprehending in it Christ and his righteousnes,
is counted for righteousnes unto him, because it settles him in the state of a righteous man: which tenet, according to the plaine, and direct importance of the words. If it be Mr. VVs. opinion, and judgement indeed, in this controversie; I cannot sufficiently wonder, what oracle he consulted with, about this serious and sad War he hath made against those Notes of mine I left with him, which I know as certainely have nothing in them, little nor much, against this opinion; as I know that Mr. VV. hath misused them with his yron intellect. I passe by many other things, which the Answerer hath let fall in the carriage of this his first Argument, obnoxious enough to the obelisque, because I would deliver both my selfe and reader, upon as good termes of dispatch, as conveniently may be.

p.hi: A second Argument to confirme the expositions, is drawne
from the Apostles wordes; ver. 4. The strength of this argument (if it hath any) may be considered of, in this Syllogisme.

list.item: That thing which is counted for righteousnes, bringeth with it a reward to the beleever, which is counted not of debt, but of grace (which reward is eternall life, as he rightly enough supposeth.)
But it is the righteousnes and satisfaction of Christ, not faith, that brings the reward of eternall life with it.
Therefore it is the righteousnes and satisfaction of Christ, and not faith, that is imputed for righteousnes to a beleever.

div.p:
I answere, first to the Proposition, by distinguishing that expression, bringeth with it a reward, out of it's ambiguity, whereof the Disputer makes his whole advantage in this Argument (being indeed his owne Language, and not the Language of that Scripture, upon which he
pretends to build his Argument) A thing may be sayd to bring with it a reward, two severall waies at least (besides many others,) either first by way of voluntary and free Covenant, or compact; or secondly, by way of merit, or just retribution, and compensation. As for example, a man may promise to as many as he pleaseth, that if they will but come over the way to him, he will give them the same money or reward, upon their coming, which the Law appointeth (or which equity and conscience would allow) to a Labourer for 7 dayes worke or Labour. In this case, the crossing the way onely, by vertue of the promise made upon such termes, brings the same reward with it, which the labour, and travaile of 7 dayes doth. If Mr W. takes the phrase of bringing with it a reward in the former sense, viz. by way of Covenant, the proposition is granted for truth: but then his assumption will halt right downe; Because Faith brings with it a reward in this sense, as well as the satisfaction of Christ doth in the other. If he meanes the clause in the other sense, viz. by way of merit: so the pr • position is to be arrested for falshood; for that which is accounted for righteousnes, doth not necessarily bring with it a reward, upon such termes, or in such a way. God in a gracious, and free Covenant, hath promised the same (if not greater) reward, to those that shall beleeve in Iesus Christ, which he hath promised to those that shall keepe the whole Law.

To the Assumption I likewise answere, that it is sick of that common disease in argumentation, which they call, fallacia divisionis. Those things are divided and put asunder, which God hath joyned together, viz. Christ and Faith, in bringing the great reward of eternall life unto the creature. See Ioh. 3. 16. Ioh. 6. 40. Rom. 5. 1. 2. besides other places (without number) of like importance: in all which, Faith or beleeving in Christ, is found in perfect conjunction with Christ himselfe, (not in opposition to him, as here it is) about the
matter of iustification and salvation. It's true, there is an opposition betweene Christ and Faith, even in the businesse of iustification; but this is in the manner, not in the matter it selfe of iustification: for both iustifie Christ and faith (Rom 5. 1, 2.) and consequently, both bring eternall life: but Christ doth it in that way which is meet for him and proper to him, and Faith doth it in another way proper to it. Christ iustifieth, by way of merit, satisfaction, and attonement-making with God for sinne: Faith iustifieth, as ordained by God to bring men into Communion and fellowship of that ransome, attonement, or satisfaction which Christ hath made. Therefore this minor proposition also is manifestly false, which makes an opposition betweene Christ and Faith in iustification it selfe (wherein the Scriptures still make them to accord) whereas the opposition that is betweene them, stands in the severall manner, or diversity of influence into the same iustification.

His third argument followeth, which is built cleane besides the foundation it claimeth, which is the sixt and seventh verses of this Chapter, where God is said to impute righteousnes without workes to him that beleeveth. This Argument, if any thing at all can bee made of it, (which indeed is very little) must rise up in this forme of reason.

If the thing imputed by God, be righteousnes, and no righteousnes else is to bee found amongst mankind, but Christs perfect righteousnes onely, then must the righteousnes of Christ, needs be that which is imputed for righteousnes.

To this argument I answere. First that the conclusion which he here raiseth from the promises, viz that Christs righteousnes must needs be that which is imputed for righteousnes to a beleever, is diametrally opposite to himselfe, in severall passages of this discourse already
examined, and particularly to what hee affirmed towards the close of his first argument, viz. that the Faith of a man, which doth not rest on his owne workes for iustification, comprehending in it Christ and his righterousnes, is imputed for righteousnes unto him. Surely faith comprehending the righteousnes of Christ, and righteousnes of Christ comprehended by Faith, are as farre differing one from the other, as Mr. Ws. opinion and mine are in this controversie, take them at their greatest elongation.

Secondly, I answere more particularly and fully, that had Mr. W. understood the Apostles phrase, of imputing righteousnes (verse 6.) he would never have sought footing for any such argument here. He supposeth, that when God is said to impute righteousnes to a beleever, he must needs have a proper, literall and preexistent righteousnes for the matter of such his imputation, or otherwise he conceiveth the Apostles expression cannot stand, which supposition we may number amongst many other Mr. Ws. mistakes in this his answere, and yet not doe it the least wrong: For

First it is not here said, that God imputeth
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (with an article) a righteousnes; but indefinitely, and without an article, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
righteousnes, which is a faire intimation (at least) that he doth not here speake of any particular or speciall righteousnes fixed in any subject, as the righteousnes of Christ is.

Secondly if by righteousnes here said to bee imputed by God, be meant the righteousnes of Christ, then according to the tenor of Mr. Ws. owne exposition, formerly mentioned, the strayne of the Apostle in this passage must be this, that God imputeth the righteousnes of Christ, for the righteousnes of Christ, to him that beleeveth see page 11.

Thirdly, that imputing righteousnes to a beleever, which is here ascribed to God is said to be an imputing righteousnes, without workes. Now the righteousnes of
Christ is so far from being a righteousnes without works, that workes are the very substance and essence of it. If it be objected and said, that this is meant concerning a mans owne works, that God imputes the righteousnes of Christ unto him, without th • se, not otherwise; To this I answere, First that such a distinction or limitation as this is, hath no foundation, at al either in this or any other Scripture. Secondly, here is not the least necessity, or occasion to invocate the aid or assistance of any such distinction. Here is no streight or difficultie against which we should be relieved by it. Now to coyne distinctions, where there is neither ground in Scripture, nor necessity in reason for it, is no les then (being interpreted) to coyne new Scriptures. Thirdly (and lastly) it is but vaine and frivolous, (especially quoad homines, in respect of those that maintaine Mr. Ws. way of imputation, because they hold, that this righteousnes of Christ imputed; by vertue of this imputation becomes or is made ours, so, or upon such termes, as if it were in deed, and in truth, properly and personally ours, and performed by our selves. But

Fourthly, if by righteousnes, which God is here said to impute, be meant the righteousnes of Christ, then is the description or explication of this imputed righteousnes which immediately followeth, (verse 7. and 8.) very impertinent and unproper, being conceived and layd downe in these three expressions, the forgivenesse of iniquities, the covering of sinnes, the not imputing sinne. The imputing of Christs righteousnes (in the sence pretended) is much more then the forgivenesse of iniquities; or the not imputing sinne. As the putting on of glorious apparell upon a man, is much more, then not to cloath him with ragges. Therefore

Fifthly, (and lastly) by Gods imputing righteousnes in this place, is meant, onely his justifying men, or (according to Mr. Ws. owne Interpretation of this Scripture phrase, pag. 10. of this his discourse) a dealing with men, and using them accordingly, as if they were righteous. To
• mpute righteousnes, is a short periphrasis, or description, of the act of absolution, iustification, with reference to the rights and priviledges, belonging thereunto, as to impute sinne, expresseth the Act of charge, or condemnation, with reference to the evil or punishments ensuing thereupon. In this sense you shall find the very phrase of imputing righteousnesse, or righteousnes imputed, used in the eleventh verse of this Chapter, for passive iustification, or, being iustified, where the Apostle hath these words concerning Abraham, that he should be the Father, (i. e. the grand example, patterne, or leader) of all that beleeve, not being circumcised, that righteousnesse might be, (or rather should be) imputed to them also, that is, that they should be justified as he was. Let the best Interpreters be consulted withall about the sense of this phrase, Imputing righteousnesse (in this place), I do not beleeve any one will be found to contradict the Interpretation now given, or by righteousnesse, to understand the righteousnes of Christ. Certaine I am, that as far as my short Librarie will reach, I have my Bookes, my Friends, in this exposition: Ergo justitia Dei (saith Musculus upon the place) quae gratis imputatur, est non imputari peccatum. that is, the righteousnes which God here freely imputeth, is the not imputation of sinne, which (according to his opinion, againe, and againe, expressed both in this Chapter, and elsewhere) is nothing else but iustification it selfe. Notandum est, (saith he, a little before the wordes cited) remissionem pecatorum esse iusticiam nostram: i. It is from hence to be observed, that remission of sinnes is our righteousnes, (or justification) and so goeth on to demonstrate this conclusion from the context. For brevities sake, I forbea • e other Authors, as Calvin, Peter Martyr, Gualter, &c. in whose Commentaries upon these two places, there is not the least intimation that by the word righteousnes, should be meant the righteousnes of Christ. And thus you see the doome of Mr. Ws. third Argument, which is, to vanish into nothing.

div.head: His fourth Argument followes, but succeeds not, neither: if the Author would have pleased to have given it any Shape or forme, it must have bin this.
div.p: If that which is here sayd to be imputed to Abraham, is for righteousnes to justification, and there be nothing that will serve for such righteousnes, but that which is found in Christ our mediator, then must somewhat in Christ, here be sayd to be imputed to Abraham, and not his faith. But the Antecedent in this proposition, is true. Therefore the Consequent must needs be true also; and so it must be somewhat in Christ, viz. his righteousnes that is sayd here to be imputed to Abraham.

There is nothing in this Argument, but what (for the substance of it) was contained in the two former, and hath bin already sufficiently answer'd. Not to repeat that which I observed in answere to his former Argument, viz. That the conclusion which here he seekes to establish, makes every whit as much, and as directly against himselfe, as against me: I onely add this (to stop the mouth of importunity) that there is indeed nothing that will serve meritoriously unto iustification, but the righteousnes or satisfaction of Christ; but there are severall things that may serve ministerially, or instrumentally thereunto. The word of God may as well, and as properly, be sayd to iustifie men (instrumentally) as to give them an inheritance amongst those that are sanctified. Act. 20. 32. And so the Minister of God, may be as well sayd to iustifie men (instrumentally, or ministerially) as to save them, which yet is ascribed to him. 1 Tim. 4. 16. And so faith it selfe, (I meane faith in Christ) is in 20 places sayd, sometimes to save men, sometimes to iustifie men, viz. instrumentally, or ministerially, being (as it were) the Officer appointed by God, to bring men into part and fellowship, of that righteousnes, or iustification which Christ hath purchased, and procured, for the
world: and is therefore sayd to be imputed unto them for righteousnes (or unto righteousnes,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) because God requireth nothing more of them to their iustification, but onely to beleeve in his Son Iesus Christ.

Mr. Ws. Fift, and last argument, comes now upon the Stage, but hath such a viz or upon the face of it, that a man cannot tell of what Shape or complexion it is, only thus far the thing is evident, from his owne wordes, that here he Starts, or rather Coniures up a new Conclusion, as far differing from what he laboured to conclude in his 4 former arguments, as the East is from the West. For thus he writes here (stylo novo) that the imputing, or counting a thing for righteousnes, is no more but DECLARING a man thereby to be righteous, and giving him the testimony of righteousnes, &c. And this he labours in the fire, to prove from that clause, in Psal. 106. ver. 31. where Phineas zealous act in executing judgement, is sayd to be imputed to him for righteousnes. So that by his reasoning in this place, he seemes plainely to deny, that a man is constituted, or made righteous, or truely, and really iustified by the imputation of Christs righteousnes, or satisfaction it selfe unto him, but onely that he is declared to be such, and to receive a testimony thereby that he is such. If his meaning be otherwise, his words and he are of two mindes. If this be to reason, or to rove, let reasonable men judge. But,
Omnis Aristippum decuit color, that is, Brave Aristippus all things did become.

Yet doth not the Scripture he alledgeth, prove that heterogeneall conclusion of his, for that Clause, of Gods imputing that zealous act of his for righteousnes, doth not import any testimony from God, of his personall righteousnesse,
or of his justified estate before God, but onely of the righteousnesse or justifiablenesse of that particular act. Videbatur (saith Musculus upon the place) factū Phine as et crudele inse, et temerariū respectu personae: Ideo ex ipso ore Dei, &c. i. e. This fact of Phine as seem'd cruell in itselfe, and rash, in respect of the person: wherefore it was expressed by the mouth of God himselfe, that he was righteously zealous, and had the honour of the Priesthood, added; as a testimony that that his fact was approved of God. If I were in Mr. Ws. case, I could not tell how to bring over this Orthodox Author to me, in such an interpretation: but Autolycus had an art to make
div.q: Candida de ingris, et de candentibus atra.
White Cowes of black, and black of white againe.
div.p: In the conclusion of this Argument, he tells us, (in effect) that were it not for feare of writing a large volume, he would insist upon humane testimonies, and the opinons of Orthodox expositors, for the further proofe of his exposition. So that (it seemes) he hath hitherto insisted onely upon himselfe, and his owne opinion, in his exposition, which I verily beleeve: and for his humane testimonies, whereof (Fencer-like) he boasts. I am full of jealousie, that they would prove no better then his Divine testimonies have bin, which (as you have seen) have bin as little to his purpose, as his adversary could wish them.

div.head: The Confutation of the false exposition made by Socinus, Mr. W. pag. 18, 19. &c. and other Heretiques, his Disciples, as Wotton, Goodwin, and their Companions.
div.p:
Bona verba quaeso, Good Sir, good wordes I pray you. I am sorry, you should turne a Heretique-maker in your old dayes; you had better (a great deale) make Candle-sticks.
The Pope makes Saints, and Mr. W. makes Heretiques; which (thinke we) is the honester Profession? as for their Art and Authority, in their Professions, I take them to be much the same. How either Wotton, or Goodwin, became either Heretiques, or Disciples of Socinus, or why they should be so accounted or called, the accuser of his Brethren doth not shew.

But though Mr. W. might make bold to sacrifice the Name and Credit of that hiobular fellow, Goodwin, upon the service of his furious fancy; it may be, he might thinke him good for little else: yet the worth, learning, and reputation, of the other, might have bin a bridle in his lips, to have kept him from falling so foule upon him, especially having now taken Sanctuary in the Grave: which should be a priviledged place (at least for the Servants of God) from the rage of tongues.

Mr Wotton was a man I never knew (by face); but as well by his writings, as by the generall report, and testimony, of those that knew him, and somebody else, it is easie to determine which was the Thistle, and which the Cedar in Lebanon.

q.l: Thersites yet alone would needs with foule mouth bluster,
Who knew to speak at large, but to his owne disgrace,
Gainst Princes vainely with bold words to fluster, &c.

div.p:
But how unsavory, importune, and impudent, Mr Ws. charge of Socinianisme upon the other, and the opinion maintain'd by him in this controversie, is, hath been discovered already, and (I thinke) so fully, that Mr. W.
will have much adoe to cover it againe. Besides, in making me Socinian, and Heretick, for what I hold concerning the imputation of faith, he cloatheth himselfe with the same shame, affirming the very same thing which I doe herein, more then once and againe, in this his worthy Answere. And whether that which was observed in the beginning of his fifth and last Argument, doth not smell ranker and stronger, of the Socinian Dunghill, then any thing that ever was maintained by me, I referre to men that have their noses about them, to judge.

Concerning his Confutation, of the false exposition, made by Socinus, Goodwin, Wotton, &c. (as he pretendeth) upon which he very bountifully bestoweth 8 whole pages and upwards, I verily beleeve, that none of all the three, nor any of their companions (as the courtesie of his pen complements with he knowes not whom) ever conceived, or delivered that exposition, upon which he poureth out his wrath in black, in so lasting a storme: but it is a man of Paper, made and set up by himselfe, to exercise his Artillerie, and to keepe his hand in ure. And therefore it is pitty to trouble him in all this discourse, since he doth no body any harme, but onely finds himselfe exercise, and imployment, with his owne shadow. As for the other two, I shall leave them to stand or fall, (in this exposition) by their owne writings, onely this I cannot but think and say, that Mr. W. surely rather dreames, then reades what mens opinions, and Interpretations are: yea though, he hath their Bookes and writings, before him, yet he seemes feerefull to trust, or beleeve these, and thinkes it more safe to relie upon one stragling imagination of his owne, for the certaintie of their opinions, then upon the plainest, and most expresse words uttered by themselves. If I were to begin againe, I would not reason with such a Spirit for Shoo-buckles.

But for this tempestuous, and fulminant quarter, of his discourse, wherein he layes on sore, where it lights
(but that is no where but on his owne fancie) I shall passe the lighter over it, (that so I may hasten to what he hath in particular charge against me) because here is little, but what (in effect) he had sayd before, and hath bin accordingly answered already; except it be some higher and fouler streyns of portentuous revilings: to all which, the best answere is, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : The Lord rebuke thee.
I shall onely propound (and that with as much brevity as may be) some sober and calme questions to him, about some particulars in these pages.

First I would know, from what Fountaine, Mr. W. drank that draught of Divinity, that Faith in Iesus Christ, whereby the Scriptures still affirme a man to be justified. Rom. 5. 1. 2. &c. taken in a proper sense, should be a part of our obedience to the Law? pag. 18. Certainely, intire obedience to the whole Law, was required of Adam in the state of innocency, but no man (I thinke the man of exceptions onely excepted, Mr. W. I meane) will affirme, that Adam in this condition, was bound to beleeve in Iesus Christ, for his justification, the Law not being of Faith (as the Apostle affirmeth, Gal. 3. 12.)
Secondly I would know, where either Wotton or Goodwin teach, that wee are justified (meritoriously, or else the charge vanisheth) by a worke of obedience to the Law? Ibidem.

Thirdly, how Mr. W. proves, that the righteousnes
imputed to Abraham was a perfect conformity to the Law? page 19.
Fourthly how it followeth, that God must needes erre lye, and judge unrighteously, if hee, imputeth righteousnes to any man without workes? ibidem.

Againe how Mr. W. proveth that the imputation of faith for righteousnes, makes the satisfaction of Christ, and his perfect fulfilling the Law, a vaine and needlesse thing? Mr. G. conceiveth, that it establisheth both the one and the other. Ibidem.

Againe: how Mr. W. can bring it about either by Scripture or reason, that the making of Christs satisfaction ours, as truely as if we had fulfilled the Law in our persons, should bee a meanes, whereby God is revealed to be infinitely just, mercifull and wise? Mr. G. conceiveth, that if Christs satisfaction were made ours upon no better termes, then as if wee had fulfilled the Law in our owne persons, it would stand us in little stead for our iustification: because he supposeth, that man having once sinned and fallen, could never have beene iustified by the fulfilling of the Law in his owne person, though he had fulfilled and kept it as perfectly as Christ did, a thousand times over. page 20.

Againe whether Mr. W. doth not thinke, that God did dispense with his iustice, when he passed by the sinner, and inflicted the punishment of death upon the innocent? or whether hee will call either the one, or the other, an act of iustice? Mr. G. conceiveth that Gods iustice led him directly to the sinner, to execute vengeance upon him: and that it was his mercy that led him aside from him that had deserved death, to another that had not deserved it. Ibidem.

Againe: what should move Mr. VV. to thinke or say, that those that hold imputation of Faith for righteousnes, should deny Communion with Christ in his satisfaction: when as Mr. G. still affirmeth, that that faith which is imputed for righteousnes, is ordained by God to bring men into Communion, and fellowship with Christ in his satisfaction: and by vertue of such ordination, iustifieth instrumentally, or (which is the same) is imputed for righteousnes? page 19.

Againe: how doth Mr. VV. prove, that the Authors of Imputation of faith for righteousnes, deny the infinite iustice of God to stand in strength, or to require such a satisfaction as Christ God and man made? page 22. when as they conceive no possibility of such imputation, but by vertue of such satisfaction: neither can they imagine
any such faith, as they conceive to bee imputed for righteousnesse, without supposing a Mediatour, God and man, on whom it should rest, and who gives it that very nature and being which it hath. It is true, they deny, that the iustice of God simply and absolutely required such a satisfaction as Christ, God and man made: but upon supposition, that God would bring many sonnes to Glory, and save that which was lost, they deny it not. But their denyall, or not denyall in this kind, hath little dependance upon the point of imputation.
Again how doth it appeare, that the men under the lash of Mr. Ws. tongue, hold, that God by his Soveraigne power, may doe and will things contrary to his iustice (p. 22.)

Againe: how doth it appeare, that to count or accept that for righteousnes, (or unto righteousnes) which is not righteousnes (that is a legall righteousnes) must needs be contrary to Gods justice: whereas Mr. W. himself holdeth, that God accepts Christs righteousnes and satisfaction, for every mans personall righteousnes, that beleeveth; which yet I presume, himself will not say, is every mans personal righteousnes, in deed and in truth: at least not that personall righteousnes, for, and instead of which it is (according to his mind) so accepted p 22. But of this enough, and enough before.

Againe where Mr. VV. findes it, that either VVotton or Goodwin, deny Christs righteousnes, to bee the righteousnes of true beleevers, page 22. Indeed they deny it, sensu VValkeriano, that is, Apocrypho; to be the righteousnes by which they are formally iustified in the sight of God: but they affirme it to bee that righteousnes, by which, and by which alone, they are iustified meritoriously in the sight of God. But they affirme it to be that righteousnesse by which, and by which alone, they are iustified meritoriously in the sight of God. And this they conceive imports as full, as deepe, as intire a propriety in it, as that Apocryphall propriety which Mr. W. would (if he knew how) entitle them unto.

Againe, where the men he wot's of, argue, that the righteousnesse of one, cannot be sufficient for all the Elect▪ (pag. 23.) whereas they maintaine, the righteousnesse and satisfaction, of Christ, to be sufficient, both for all the Elect, and Non-elect too, but with a Scriptures sufficiencie too, not an apocryphall. That the same acts of obedience to the Morall Law, should the Letter, and formality of them, make a morall, or Legall righteousnesse, that should fit all men, and women, of all Callings, and Conditions, in the world, they hold it every whit, as senselesse, and unreasonable, as that the same garment should fit all Statures, and Proportions of bodyes, or the same Shoe, all feet of all sizes; And they conceive the Scriptures to be as far from affirming the one as the other. And yet they fully beleeve, that the righteousnesse and satisfaction of Christ, taken together, in the Spirit, or merit, of them, are, as of absolute necessity, so of absolute sufficiency, for the justification of a world of Sinners.

Againe, what colour, or appearance of reason, Mr. VV. can bring, that they should overthrow the Doctrine of Redemption, and Christs satisfaction, who deny, that men may be properly sayd to have satisfied Gods justice themselves in Christ? pag. 23. Certainely, a difference about propriety of speaking, doth not overthrow a fundamentall Article of faith. But Mr. VV. (Womanlike) molliter irasci non novit, knowes not how to chide under Heresie and Blasphemy: well, for all this great wrath that is boyled up to such a height in Mr. VVs. brest, against me, I shall still thinke it safer, both to thinke and say, that Christ satisfied the justice of God for me, then that I my selfe satisfied the iustice of God for my selfe.

Againe, What monstrousnesse of opinion it is, or what contrariety there is in it, either to common sense or reason, to deny any formall legall righteousnes, in iustification: iustification, consisting onely in remission of sinnes,
(as both Scriptures, and Calvin, and many a worthy Divine more with him, joyntly testifie) pag. 23. as I have proved at large, elsewhere.

Againe, What those expresse words are, Rom 5. 19. and 8. 4. and 10. 4. wherein the Apostle should affirme, that the faithfull are constituted and made formally righteous, by the obedience of Christ communicated, and imputed unto them, pag 24. I cannot in all those Scriptures find so much as one EXPRESSE word▪ either of the communication, much lesse of the imputation of Christs righteousnesse to the faithfull, least of all, of their being made formally righteous by such imputation. And yet if Mr. VV. could be persuaded to use a mans words kindly, I would grant also, that we are iustified even formally too, by the communication of Christs righteousnesse, and satisfaction, to us, viz. In as much as by such communication we obtaine remission of sinnes, which is our formall iustification. Therefore we do not deny a formall righteousnesse in iustification (as Mr. VV. ignorantly, or falsely, which he will, chargeth us) but onely a legall, formall, righteousnes.

Againe, where he finds it to be any branch of the Pelagian Heresie, to deny that Adams posterity, are made formally sinners, with Adams sinne imputed to them in the Letter, and formality of it? pag. 24.

Againe, Who they are that deny, that Infants, dying before they commit actuall sinne, are punished by death, because they are guilty of Adams sinne; or affirmeth, that God out of his iustice destroyeth innocent Babes? pag 24. But Mr. VV. may please to understand (if he be not too much inamourd upon the lovelesse face of confusion) that it is one thing to have the guilt of Adams sinne derived upon his posterity, another thing to have the act of his sinne (in the Letter, and formality of it) imputed to his posterity, so that for such imputation, they should all be destroyed. I do not think the former was ever denyed, either by VVotton, or Goodwin. Neither
do I thinke the latter will ever be proved by Mr. VV. And therefore ridiculous is that qualification, which he seekes to apply to ease the destruction of innocent Babes (as he calls them) in affirming, that by the word and Law of God they were not to die for the sinnes of their Parents, unlesse they be partakers with them, either by communion▪ and imputation, or by imitation, and approbation, (as if imitation, and approbation, were no communion with them in their sinnes, being indeed, the greatest, and deepest of all) or as if the destruction of these Babes, were at all lightned, or eased, because God is pleased to impute their Parents sinnes unto them: or as if the iustice of God in the destruction of such Babes, were ever the more cleared, or iustified, by Mr. VVs. imputation of the acts of the Parents sinne, then by the charging of the guilt, or demerit, of such sinnes upon them: especially considering, that howsoever the act of God, involving Adams posterity in the guilt of his sinne, or exposing them to condemnation for it, was a righteous and iust act in him; that is, was nothing but what he might lawfully, and iustly doe: yet was it no act of his iustice, whereunto he was necessitated, but an act of his will and free pleasure: as Dr. Twist, and other Divines teach, and acknowledge▪ For the charg he puts upon us of the Children of Korah, be shall do well to name who have made that use of them, he speakes of, and let them answere for them.

Againe, How they that deny the imputation of Christs
righteousnes, (viz. In the Letter, and formality of it) to beleevers, do hereby give or ascribe as much iustification by it to Infidels, and impenitent Reprobates, as to beleevers themselves? (pag. 25.) when as they so expressely affirme and maintaine, that Faith is the onely meanes ordained by God, to bring men into communion with Christ, and to give them part in that great benefit of Redemption, which was purchased for the world by him.

Againe, how Mr. W. can possibly avoyd the same absurdity himselfe, which he falsly charg'd his adversaries with, in the former quere viz the bringing in of Infidels, as well as Beleevers, for iustification, by Christ, when-as he affirmeth the new Covenant by Christ, to be no waies conditionall, nor faith itselfe, to be any condition of the Covenant, to be performed on our part, for our iustification, and salvation▪ In which conceit (certainly) he is, A perse A. and hath no man either at his righthand or at his left, to stand by him, or releive▪ him therein.

Againe (once more) how Mr. W. can prove it to be a mistake (I shall be content to abate and ease him of the fag end of the tasque, the grossenesse, and absurdity, of it) to hold or say, that iustification and life▪ are promised, upon condition of beleeving, pag. 25. Either they are promised absolutely, and without all condition, or they are promised upon some other condition, besides beleeving, or they are promised upon the condition of beleeving; or lastly, they are not promised at all. If they be absolutely and without all condition what doth faith or beleeving, conduce to the obtaining them? Mr. VVs. distinction, betweene the condition of obtaining a promise and the meanes or way of obtaining a promise, puts me in mind of the Physitians wife, in Bishop Iewell who comprimis'd a solemne difference betweene her and, some of her neighbour • women, concerning pepper, she (it seemes) affirming it to bee cold, they opposing her, by the hot tast it hath in the mouth but she under the protection of this distinction, that though it were hot in working, yet it might bee cold in operation▪ came off with Honour, and amusing her opposers with her profound learning and subtilty, carried the cause with a strong hand. If Mr. W. meets onely with such Readers, as she did opposers, his distinction betweene the condition, and the meanes of obtaining a promise, may worke wounders and make him seeme something. But in denying faith to be the
condition of the Gospell or new Covenant; hee doth not onely hang out the flag of defyance against VVotton, and Goodwin, but swims against the streame of the most confessedly Orthodox Divines of our owne Church, yea and opposeth those that take part with him in this controversie; and are the ablest maintainers of his Faith therein. For Bishop Downeham expressely affirmeth, the condition whereon the Gospell promiseth justification, to be Faith in Christ, as the condition of the Law, to bee our owne perfect and personall obedience: And builds this condition of the Gospell, upon those very Scriptures, which Mr. W. hath rejected. For (saith he) the Gospell saith, If thou beleeve in Christ, thou art justified, and shalt be saved. (Rom. 10. 5.) the Law, If thou dost these things thou shalt live thereby. B. Downham: in his Doctrine of Christian Liberty, on Iohn 8. 36. page 44. By which it appeares, that hee makes Faith the condition of the Gospell, in the same manner, and upon the same termes, that workes, or perfect obedience, was of the Law. And Calvin on Rom. 10. 8. to the same purpose: Ex hâc distinctionis nota &c. that is, from this distinction we gather, that as the Law requires workes, so the Gospell requires nothing, but that men bring Faith to receive the grace of God. That great light of our Church, Mr. Perkins, could not discerne the subtilty of Mr. Ws. distinction neither, but without scruple, affirmes Faith to be the condition of this Covenant. In the Covenant of grace (saith hee) two things must be considered: the substance, and the condition &c. the condition is, that wee for our parts, are by Faith to receive the foresaid benefits (Reform. Cath: of iustific▪ Differ. 2.) So Mr. Fox, Conditio quâ propriè instificamur &c. that is, the condition whereby wee are properly iustified, is this, that wee beleeve in Christ: In his treatise of Christ freely iustifying. Againe (in the same treatise) the promise of salvation by Christ, belongs but unto some, and that under a certaine condition: So
that he never conceited that the least preiudice could arise to the freenesse of Gods grace in the Covenant of the Gospell, by making Faith the condition of it. I might heap up Testimonies (in this kind) without end, If I thought any man were of Mr. VVs. opinion in this point, but himselfe. Nay I am certaine that himselfe is not of his owne opinion: because immediately after he had rejected Faith, with great indignation, from being any condition of the Gospell, hee writeth thus: In all which and the like places, there is no condition of the Covenant propounded, but onely the meanes and the way to receive blessing, or the quality and condition, by which men are made capable &c. As faire and goodly a contradiction, as a man shall meet withall in a sommers day, or seven yeares reading: there is no condition, but onely a condition. O acutenesse! quibus Coelo te laudibus aequem! I see many other things in this limb of his discourse, that deserve the Censors rod: but Non ego si centum pennas &c.

Having already proved the Socinian and Arminian Mr. W. p. 26.
opinion, to be most false &c. I proceed to discover the weaknesse and absurdity of Mr. Goodwins Arguments in the second chapter of his Socinian discourse &c.

They that will beleeve Mr. VV. may; but otherwise (setting his owne sayings aside, as I am constrained to doe) he hath left his Reader at full liberty to doubt and question, whether he hath so much as touch'd either the Socinian or Arminian opinion (touching the point in hand) in all his discourse hitherto; because he hath not proved so much as any one word, of all those things wherewith he hath charged them, either out of any of their owne writings, or from the testimony of any approved Author against them, yea they that will please to peruse, and consider what hath bin already said in this Reply, will easily conceive that Mr. VV. doubtlesse was in the midst of Samaria, when bee supposed himselfe to have beene in Dothan, (at least would
have perswaded his Reader, that there he was.)

Well: But though he hath miscarried and misbehaved himselfe in the front, he will now play the man in the reere, and gather up the credit and reputation hee hath scattered. Now he hath to deale with Goodwin alone, he will be revenged on him, he and his Socinian discourse shall pay for all. Whethe • Mr. W. hath an • ll tongue, in his head, or no, I know not: but sure I am▪ that the discourse he speakes of, was not Socinian, till he cal • 'd it so: neither was so much as one thrid of that spinning in all the whole pi • ce. But I hope Mr. Ws. tongue from henceforth, will be no slander. However, the second chapter of this discourse, Socinian or not Socinian, the Lion hath go •• en betweene his teeth, and threatens to teare it into a thousand pieces. And first of a • l, Sampson-like, he rouseth and shakes himselfe, and sets himselfe cheerefully to stand against the truth.

How he meanes to proceed, he sufficiently declares in his beginning, viz. by the rule and method of malice, and frowardnesse. If the first fruites bee sowre and uncleane, so is the whole lump like to bee also. What I speake indefinitely, and in the generall, concerning the hard measure that is oft-times measured out by men to those that speake the truth from God unto them, hee misuseth and perverts, as if I assum'd all to my selfe, and would leave nothing for him.

But the rude multitude of my Disciples are a great offence unto him, by proclaiming mee to bee the great light of the Church &c. (Who Mr. W. meanes by my rude disciples, I know not: neither (I beleeve) doth he know himselfe. If I knew them, I would send them to him to learne better manners, and to be taught more elegant behaviour. But they proclaime mee the great light of Gods Church. Surely this was whil'st Mr. W. slept: these rude fellowes got in by the dore of his nostrills, and so clamber'd up into his Crowne, and there playd their prankes, and made that sacrilegious
proclamation. But more soberly: suppose these fellowes indeed spake such wordes of me, what will Mr. W. give me, and I will pull off the fooles bable from my head, and he shall have it to set on his: if he longs, his longing shall not cost him much: he shall have it at a very low rate. I will entreat my disciples to proclaime him, this great light &c. But the multitude of my disciples stick in his stomack too. Surely the shadowes of the Mountaines seeme men to him: or else he lookes through the multiplying glasse of envy. And yet I conceive the number of the men hee meanes, may be somewhat encreased, by his owne unreasonable, un-Christian, and furious proceedings against me. An unmercifull enemy many times begets friends.

But how shall I doe? he wounds mee on the heele, and takes me tardy with a contradiction. Well: I see it is no halting before a cripple. A man cannot counterfeit a contradiction, but Mr. W. a man so much overseene in contradictions, will find it out. But Contradiction, where art thou? and what is thy name? Here Sir, and my Name is,

lg.l: The Holy Ghost is the best Iudge for determining controversies:
The Holy Ghost leaves his meaning (in many things) to be debated by men.

div.p: Thou a Contradiction? who made thee a Contradiction? Mr. W. Sir. But how could he possibly make thee a Contradiction? by a wrench that he hath, whereby he can turne light into darknes, and truth into errour, and the honour of God into blasphemy, and streight things into crooked, and the fairest consistencies into contradictions. Well, goe thy wayes: thou hast fallen into bad hands: but doe but pray men to looke well upon thee, and the charme will be dissolved, and thy native shape shall returne unto thee: thou shalt be no longer a contradiction.

Immediately after, he springs a new game, and in
that phrase used by me, stamped with a rationall authority, he discovers the Arminian Heresie, and falls foule upon right reason. Indeed it is no strange thing, for an angry man to fall out with right reason, because they are seldome friends.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 :
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . that is,
'Twixt Men, and Lions, no league firme will stand,
But to destroy each other still they band.

But I confesse Mr. W. may bee the better borne with, if hee calls for club-Law against right Reason, and would by all meanes have it knock'd downe, because it is still an enemy to him, and still crosseth and opposeth and contradicteth him in his enterprises. And yet presently after he had cried out against me for an Arminian Heretick in the point of Right Reason, he makes a second out-crie upon mee, for running away, from right reason, in the whole progresse of my disputation. Sure the man is not to be dealt with, or pacified, neither with right reason nor without it; but is as full of contradictions in his Moralls, as in his intellectualls, that the one might not laugh at the other. But it stands him in hand in the businesse hee is now about to turne Arminian Heretick himselfe (if that be an Arminian Heresie to make use of Reason in the Interpretation of Scripture) because the letter of the Scripture hee is to deale with, still with-stands him in the face, and will not come neere the opinion hee maintaines, except it be brought over by a strong hand of reason and discourse. And whereas he complaines of scandalousnes in me to professe excellent things of my selfe, &c. but is not able to bring one the least word, or tittle out of all my discourse sounding that way: I am sure it is 7. times more scandalous in him, to deliver such staring
and broadsac'd untruthes. All that I speake of my self, is rather by way of disparagement, and with more modesty then he (it seemes) was able to beare: and therefore gets him up into God's Throne, and there playes Sathans part, judging the mindes and intentions of men, contrary to their doings. Iob 1. But I perceive what meat Mr. W. loves: hee is loath there should bee a Feast of excellent things, whereunto he is not invited: Well: If I have trespassed against his appetite, here, I will make him this promise (for amends) that the next time I speake such excellent things of the undeserving, he shall be the man.

His first Argument &c. In his Answere, to thatMr. VV. pag. 30. which he calls my first argument, he presently sets his Ignorance and mine together by the eares, and raiseth a fearefull dust and combustion betweene them. Let his be the Conqueror, and mine the Gras-hopper. First he arraignes me at the barre of his supposed learning, for those heinous crimes of Ignorance in Rhetorick and Logick: Secondly for shewing my selfe a bold lying Sophister, which hang together, as the testimonies of those false witnesses, that came to give in evidence against Christ, Mar. 14. 59. Ignorance in Logick destroyes Sophistrie, as ignorance in the Scriptures doth Divinity. Well: his charge (you see) is sore: but his proofes as ridiculous and contemptible. Hee demonstrates my ignorance in Rhetorick, thus: because it is counted an excellent ornament of speech, to continue a trope &c. which is, as if I should prove Mr. W. to be ignorant in Divinity, because in the beginning God made heaven and earth. If Mr. W. should deny this, the proofe were somewhat to the purpose: but not denying it, it is no proofe at all against him, but that possibly he may be a learned Divine notwithstanding.

My ignorance in Logick, he proves from the unquestionable profūdity of his own insight into that Sciēce, which appeares in this, that he is able to te • l us, that in Logick he
is counted a bould lying Sophister, who holds, that a Syllogisme; a true and perfect Argument, hath a proposition, which is manifestly false. I confesse I do not remember, that ever I met with this golden rule to measure a bold lying Sophister by, so punctually in any Logique, or Logician I have read: and though I easily grant Mr. VVs. reading to have out-compassed mine, yet I beleeve, that neither hath he met with this rule in all his sphere of reading; but we have it here new out of the mint of his owne braine, the fire is not yet out of it, Logicians are wont to speake with reason, and sobriety, and not to cal their Brethren, bold lying Sophisters: the thrid is too course ever to have bin spun unpon their Wheele; well, but let us grant this profound axiome to be true: What is the truth thereof to evince my ignorance in Logique more then my knowledge that twise two make foure, is to prove Mr. W. ignorant in Arithmetique?

But leaving these collaterall impertinences, which (I conceive) are but the crude, and indigested ebullitions of his unnaturall heate and passion, deserving rather pittie then Answer) let us (with what brevitie is possible) see what weight and substance there is in what he opposeth here against me. I argue the imputing of faith for righteousnesse in a proper sense (that is, in the very same sense, that himselfe hath formerly given, and approved againe, and againe, in this his discourse, as hath bin already observed from hence, because the phrase is so often used in this Chap. without any alteration or exchange; and affirme withall, that the imputation of Christs righteousnesse for our righteousnes (in the sense rejected in my former Chapter, and which Mr. W. must maintaine, or else I cannot count him an adversarie in the point in question) hath not the least reliefe, either from found of wordes, or sight of Letter in the Scriptures.

To this Mr. W. answers, that Ier. 26. the Lord is sayd to repent 3 sev • rall times, and that this speech is not proper &c. and that Gal. 3. the word Faith is used 10.
times in an unproper sense, &c. and hence inferres, that the frequent, and constant use of a phrase, doth not prove a proper acception of it &c. Which conclusion indefinitly taken, and in the generall, is unquestionably true: and his instances, are currant proofs hereof. I will deny nothing that he speakes with reason, but freely assent to him, and commend him; because I would encourage him to speake more upon such terms.

But yet he might have pleased here to have considered, that rule which Austine long since gave, and Divines generally have approved from him; that a literall, and proper sense in Scripture, is still to be preferr'd, where there is no necessity of rejecting it, or substituting a tropicall, or improper in the stead. And except this rule be admitted as unquestionable, the cleerest, and most expresse truths in Scripture, will still be obnoxious to dispute, and controversie, and may be tossed up and downe, by the wills, and wits of men. Now this rule wholly evacuates the strength of his answere: because in those Scriptures produced by him, there is an apparent necessity of having recourse to an improper signification of the words, because the litterall, and proper, imports a manifest contradiction, to common sense and reason; as is sufficiently evident to him that shal but a little consider those and the like Scriptures. And in such a case as this, where there is no danger or feare, that the literall sense should be taken, because the very principles of reason, are ready to cry out against it: the holy Pen-men of Scripture, may use a metaphoricall expression, 10 times together, and twenty times after that; the frequency of the repetition, will never be any proofe, or argument, of a proper, or literall signification. But in the Scripture and phrase controverted betweene Mr. VV. and me, the case is far otherwise: the literall, and proper sense, may here be taken, no rule of reason, (no nor of Religion neither, as hath bin proved both here, and elsewhere) gainsaying it, (at least not manifestly, nor notoriously contradicting i • )
and therefore the frequent, and constant use of such a phrase, is a strong inducement (at least) that the literall and proper sense is here to be imbraced.

Whereas (towards the close of this answere) he breakes out againe, and gives me a new Livery of the same Cloath, with the former, calling me bold lying Sophister, for affirming most falsly and impudently, that which he would not have to be affirmed upon this occasion, though he be not able to disprove it (nor so much as attempts to do it) because it little concernes the present question. I will gratifie his infirmity so far, as to passe it over without any further censure.

div.head: The second Argument Couched under the other, &c.
div.p: How kind and courteous an adversary have I met withall, who rather then I shall want Arguments to oppose him, will furn • sh me, at his own cost and charge, yea and (that which is yet more) with such Arguments that are too hard for himselfe, and which all his learning is not able to overthrow. As for example, out of my words, wherein I had no thoughts of any New Argument, distinct from the former, Mr. VV. raiseth this Syllogisme.

list.item: That which hath not the least releefe, either from sound of words, or sight of Letter in the Scriptures, is an untruth, and meere fiction.
The imputation of Christs righteousnesse (in the sense questioned) hath not the least releefe either from the one, or the other. Ergo.

div.p:
Mr. W. having coniur'd up this Spirit, to shew his art, and to make himselfe merry withall, presently
attempts to conjure him downe againe. But his condition in this skirmish, is as sad as that of the Vagabond Exorcists, Act. 19. who would needs be medling with, and adjuring the Spirit in one that was possessed, but the Spirit was sturdy and would not obey, but ran upon the adjurers, and overcame them and prevailed against them, so that they fled naked and wounded. v. 16. So Mr. VV. heaving at the Minor proposition, of this his owne Syllogisme, receives a wound in his reputation, and so leaves it, the proposition remaining as strong, and as unshaken, as before hee lift up his weapon against it. For going about to prove that the imputation of Christs righteousnes (in his sence) hath testimony from the expresse words and le • ter of Scripture, hee onely produceth the 4. and 11. verses of this 4. Chap. to the Romans, both which are as silent concerning any imputation of Christ's righteousnes, as Mr. VV. (on the other side) is full of words. And it hath beene already shewed and proved in this reply, that the phrase of imputing righteousnes in these two places, onely notes God's free iustification of men, or his accepting of them as righteous, without workes.

In answere to my second Argument (which he hath madeMr. VV. page 31. the third by his munificent multiplication) he either findeth (or maketh) a heape of lies mixt with contradictions (and that in one proposition onely) I see my Antagonist is two to one better at making lies, and contradictions then at judging of them, or finding them out. A man may easily deceive him with a very slender appearance of a contradiction: but those which himselfe makes are very re • ll and substantiall and can deceive no man (as we have given good proofe in particular instances, out of this his Answere, not a few.) But who would thinke that one poore proposition, could bee so mischievously bent, as to have no lesse then a heape of lies mixt with contradictions, in the belly of it? I know not how many lies goe to Mr. VVs. heape: I hope he doth not meane
any great heape: for then no man will be able to beleeve him. But I mervaile why he addes, mixt with contradictions. I cannot yet fathome his intent and meaning in this, whether he makes this addition by way of any diminution, or of further aggravation of that charge, a heape of lies. I cannot be so uncharitable in my thoughts to Mr. Ws. passion, as that that should betray him, or suffer him to speake any thing by way of favour or mitigation of any thing, that hee can come by, either by hooke or by crooke, to lay to my charge: and how on the other hand to interpret it, by way of deepening or further aggravating the charge, I know not.
