Because, a heape of lies alone, without any mixture of contradictions, is much worse, then where there is an inlaying of contradictions with it, there being no contradiction, but the one halfe of it is ever truth. But I further appeare in Mr. VVs. eyes, like a mad or a drunken man: which certainly is as perfect a signe, that his eyesight is not good, as the seeing of men walking like trees, was of the imperfection of his eyes, who was not yet recovered of his blindnesse, Mar. 8.

But let us see a little what the angry man aileth, and pick the thorne out of his finger (if wee can) which makes him rage and take on as if hee were wild. If the heape of lies mixt with contradictions be removed from before his dore, I hope his neighbours shall live in peace by him. Wee will carrie it cleane away by little and little.

The top of this heap (which must first be taken away) is a contradiction, which (for want of better sight,) hee descrieth in these wordes of mine: The Scope of the Apostle is to put men by the false way of justification, which lies through workes, and to discover the true way, by informing them what they must doe, and performe for iustification. Here because I affirme, the way of iustification by workes, to be the false way, a way wherein men cannot be iustified, and yet suppose that men must
doe somewhat, before they bee iustified, (or for their iustification) he triumphingly insults over me, as a drunken and mad man, for contradicting my selfe, as if he that doth any thing at all towards his iustification, must needs se • ke to be iustified by workes. I hope, if Iesus Christ himselfe speake as I doe in this case, Mr. VV. will presently discharge me of this contradiction, for feare of worse matters. I thinke hee will not deny, but that faith, or beleeving in Christ, is necessary to iustification (or else he will justifie the Infidells, and impenitent Reprobates hee spake of, as well as the faithfull) and certaine I am, that Christ calls this faith, or beleeving in him, a worke: This is the worke of God (saith hee to the Iewes, Ioh. 6. 29.) that yee beleeve in him, whom he hath sent: And when Paul exhorts the Philippians, to worke out their salvation with feare and trembling, he doth not exclude their faith, or beleeving in Christ. So our best and most Orthodox Divines, speak without scruple, terming that beleeving by which wee are iustified, the doing of something. Quid enim fecit Abraham, quod imputaretur ad justitiam, nisi quod credidit Deo? Musculus in Gal. 3. 6. that is, what did Abraham, that should be imputed for righteousnes, but onely beleeve God. So Mr. Perkins Reform. Cathol. concerning justification. The meaning is (saith hee) that nothing within man, and nothing that man can doe, either by nature or by grace, concurreth to the act of iustification before God, as any cause thereof, either efficient, materiall, formall, or finall, but onely faith. And I would faine know of Mr. W. whether when he beleeveth, he doth something or nothing: or when hee beleeveth, whether he beleeveth not for iustification, or that he may bee iustified. The Apostles themselves beleeved for such an end, and purpose Gal. 2. 16. We have beleeved in Iesus Christ, that wee might be iustified by the faith of Christ, surely if they might have beene justified without doing any thing at all, they might have let
this beleeving in Christ alone: which I hope Mr. W. himselfe doth not, for seare of seeking justification by workes. Yea, doth hee not in this very place, in as expresse termes (as usually he speaketh) affirme, and avouch the very same doing or worke as necessary to iustification, for which he rates m • e with that prodigious
indignation? Hee affirmes, that the Apostles whole scope is bent against iustification, by workes of our own, and to shew that all which we are to look to, is to receive that, which is freely given &c.
Questionlesse, receiving, is the doing of somewhat, and indeed one and the selfe same work, with beleeving. S • e Iohn 1. 11. 12▪ &c. besides many other Scriptures. And I marvaile from what brest he suck'd that same 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to call every thing that is done by us, if it bee iust and lawfull, a worke of the Law, (meaning the morall Law.) Surely to serve, worship, and beleeve in Iesus Christ, as Mediatour, are just and lawfull, yet no works of the morall Law, nor was Adam in his innocency bound unto them. And if Mr. W. had understood what the Scripture meanes, by workes, in opposition to grace, in the businesse of justification, he would not have condemned an innocent and cleere passage of the foule crime of a contradiction. By workes (in this case) is not meant, whatsoever may in any respect be said to bee done by a man himselfe, as if the freenesse of Gods grace in iustification, should any wayes suffer, or be destroyed, if any thing should upon any consideration, be required of him in reference to his iustification: neither Mr. W. nor all the abettors he hath under Heaven, will ever be able to prove this: but by workes, (opposed to grace, in iustification) is meant the merit of workes, or whatsoever is done, or attempted to be done by men themselves, with an opinion or intent of deserving iustification thereby. Nay the truth is, that the worke of beleeving, (as our Saviour calleth it) is so farre, from carrying any opposition in it to the freenesse of Gods grace in iustification,
that it is purposely required of men (and it onely) by him, that the freenesse of his grace in their iustification might be established. Therefore it is by Faith, that it might be by grace, Rom. 4. 16. and cap. 5. 2. VVe are said to have accesse or admittance into the grace of justification, by or through Faith. But for the perfect and intire consistence of the worke of faith, with the freenesse of Gods grace in the iustification of a sinner, consider those and such like Scriptures at leysure, Rom. 3. 24. 25. Eph. 2. 8. &c.

Well, the Heape of lies mixt with contradictions, is (I hope) well lessened by this time: the plurall number in charge, prooves but the singular in proofe, and that just nothing: hee talk'd of contradictions, as of many: but findes but one, and that one made of as faire a consistency of speech, as the Scripture it selfe useth.

But besides the contradictions, and other absurdities and untruths (observe, hee speakes more mannerly then hee did: is there not hope hee will mend?) hee findes th • se grosse errours &c. Wee are come now towards the bottome of the heap, where (it seemes) the grossest and thickest of the lies are setled. The first is, that I say, that God doth not require of us the righteousnes of Christ, &c. this hee requires of Christ himselfe. Before he comes to shew the grossenes of this errour, hee himselfe drops two grosse errours (indeed) by the way viz. That God requires nothing of us for our iustification, when as it is notoriously knowne, that he threatens damnation, except we beleeve; and to credit his saying, he cites, Rom. 3. 24. whereas the verse immediately following, quite overthrowes it, wherein the condition of faith is expresly mentioned. Hee drops yet againe a second errour (more grosse then the former) saying, that Faith is a qualification to u • , for the receiving, applying, and enjoying Christs righteousnes: that is, Faith is a qualification to us for beleeving:
for what is the receiving, applying, and enioying the righteousnes of Christ, but beleeved (as was before observed.)

But with these two errors dropping from him, it seemes his memory dropped also, for by this time he hath forgot his enterprize, and instead of proving what I had said, a grosse errour, he onely complaines of it, as a harsh unsavoury and absurd phrase. And to justifie his complaint, he tell us, that to say God requires the righteousnes of Christ, not for our iustification, but of Christ himselfe, implies, that Christ had need of iustification, and was bound to fulfill the righteousnes of the Law for himselfe: which savours of the Socinian and Samosatenian heresie, and denyes Christs God-head, with much more (as the manner of the man is)

Is not this a solid and demonstrative proofe, of the harshnesse and unsavourinesse of this saying, God requires not of us the righteousnes of Christ, &c. Hee that can make these premisses and Conclusion hang, may well set up the trade of gluing Oyster-shells, and undertake to make the yron and the clay in Nebuchadnezzars Image, mix and worke together. He that saith, that God doth not require of us the righteousnes of Christ for our iustification, doth not so much as in colour or shew, affirme, that he therefore requires it of him, for his owne justification: onely it seemes to imply, that hee required it of him for our justification: which (I conceive) is no harsh or unsavoury, but a proposition well pleasing to Mr. W. himselfe.

But setting aside the irrelativenesse and impertinency of what he affirmeth here, to what hee had in hand to proove, I could (I conceive) put some queries to him, that would a little trouble him, to make good the truth thereof in a positive way. As

First, how he can prove, that Christ had no need of iustification? Surely Christ was a iustified, or righteous person, in the sight of God. This iustification was not superfluous, or no wayes usefull to him. And whatsoever is not superfluous, we men of the lower forme of learning and understanding, judge to bee some wayes needfull.

Secondly how he would prove, that Christ was not bound to fulfill the righteousnes of the Law for himself? Certaine I am, that some Divines of our owne Church, and Nation, no whit inferiour to Mr. W. himselfe, either for choycenesse of learning or soundnesse of iudgement, (and yet neither Wotton, nor Goodwin, nor any of their Disciples) have written otherwise: Christ (saith Mr. Deering in his second Lect on the Heb.) by the spirit, still fill'd his manhood more and more with grace, till the fulnesse of all righteousnes was within him, that so his manhood might inherit salvation, according to the promise, doe this and live. But hitherto as he is righteous, so hee is righteous for himselfe, and onely that man is yet blessed which was conceived by the Holy Ghost &c.

And he that holds, that Christ as man, was not bound to fulfill the righteousnes of the Law for himselfe, dureing his continuance on Earth in the flesh, must (if hee will be true to his principles) hold with all, that Christ as man had a liberty, or dispensation from his God-head, to transgresse in respect of himselfe: and that this dispensation could not take place, or bee put in execution, onely because of that worke of Redemption, which he had undertaken. It may be this is no such Camell, but Mr. VV. can swallow, without strayning. But I hope he will not be offended, if they that stand charged with so many Heresies and blasphemies already, bee unwilling to charge themselves yet further with this also.

Thirdly I would put him upon this, to prove such an absolute inconsistency, or diametrall opposition, as he seemes
to imagine, betweene Christs fulfilling the Law for himselfe, and for us, as if at no hand they could stand together. Surely Mr. W. when he compil'd and wrote this answere, he wrote it both for himselfe, that is: for the discharge of such a conscience as he hath; and for others also, that is, for the good, benefit and instruction of mee, and many others. And Saint Bernard in that 190. Epistle, (cited by Mr. W. himselfe, afterward) speaking of the work of Redemption wrought by Christ, affirmeth it to have beene, Opus aequè nostrum, & suum, & Angelorum, that is, a worke indifferently ours, and his owne, and the Angels: and then goeth on, shewing how respectively.

Fourthly, (and lastly) it would cost him many of his thoughts, and much of his Learning, to give a sufficient and cleare accompt, how it should any way intrench, or so much as looke towards the deniall of Christs Godhead, to conceive that Christ might be bound to fulfill the righteousnes of the Law, for himselfe. I conceive it tends farre more dangerously to shake the truth of his humanity, to deny that he was any waies bound to keepe the Law for himselfe. And as the error of the vbiquitarie tends to dissolve the truth of his manhood, viâ naturali, so doth this opinion of Mr. W. (which yet he maintaines with that fearelesse confidence) as farre as yet I am able to see into it, tend to the same end, via morali.

It is marvailous improbable unto me, that hee should be the Seed of the Woman, who by the Law of his creation should not be bound, to keepe that Law, which both the man and the Woman stood bound to keepe in their innocencie. And as the personall union with the God-head, could not privilege his humane nature, or Body, against those properties which are naturall, and essentiall to it, as locality, quantity, finitenesse, commensurablenes to its place, nor communicate or convey over to it, those properties of immensitie, • ubiquity, omnipresence,
&c. which are essentiall to the Divine nature. So neither could it priviledge his manhood, against those morall habitudes, relations, or conditions, which are as essentiall to such a creature in another way, as viz. subjection unto God, obligation of serving him, and fulfilling his will, &c.

Concerning Christ's meriting his exaltation, I shall not strive with him for the present. Onely (I beleeve) wee have neither of us waded so farre (in our meditations) into those Scriptures, which speak to this point, but that we may wade yet deeper, and know more concerning it, then we do. As viz. Rev. 5. 12. Heb. 12 2. Phil. 2. 7, 8, 9, &c. Luk 24. 26. &c.
There remaine now but two little shovel-fulls more of the dunghill or heap of lies that troubled Mr. W. so excessively, to be removed, and then the street (in this place) will be cleane.

Another grosse errour (he saith) is, that I call faith and beleeving, a thing done and performed by us, when as the Apostle affirmes, and all Christians confesse that our beleeving is not of our selves, but the gift of God &c. Surely Mr. W. hath as rare a guift of making grosse errours, as King Midas had of making Gold.

Quicquid contigerat &c. that is what ere he toucht, his touch made glistering gold: so it seemes, whatsoever Mr. W. cast's his eye upon, becomes a grosse error ipso facto: but (I hope) not without bale or maine prize. Though Faith be the gift of God, that is, the grace and spirituall strength by which we beleeve: yet is there no Apostle that affirmes, nor Christian (that I know) that confesseth, that the Christians beleeving, is Gods act of beleeving: or that denyes, but that men themselves are the beleevers, though not of themselves, nor by their owne strength. But as Aristotle's Proverb is: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; that is, if water choakes mee, what then shall I drinke?
If Mr. W. makes grosse errours of such expressions as these, hee is not a man for mee to speake: when I have wash'd my hands of him this once, I hope I shall foule them no more.

Wee are now come to the very bottome of the dunghill, and are neere hand of being sweet and cleane. But the man is in some distresse of thoughts, whether hee should call that which remaineth, a grosse absurdity, or rather a blasphemy: but surely hee will be as advised in his choyce betweene them, as men are when they chuse Lobstars: he will chuse the heavier. But in this particular he deales more cowardly with me then in all the rest. Till now he came before mee and smote▪ mee in the face, his onely offence being that he did wrongfully: but now he comes behind my back, and at unawares knocks me downe to Hell with a double club, or with the Apostles yron Mace of an Anathema Maranatha, nor for any offence of mine at all, but for his owne forgery, who Ananias-like, keeps back part of my wordes, and presents what hee pleaseth for my assertion. He chargeth me, that I here maintaine, that teaching iustification by Christ, and his righteousnes, is the casting of a snare upon men, and not opening the dore of life and salvation to them. I shall need no other compurgators from this crime, but onely the setting downe mine owne wordes, which are these: whereas to have said thus unto them, that they must be iustified by Christ, or by Christs righteousnes, and withall not to have plainely signified, what God requireth of them, and will accept at their hand, to give them part and fellowship in that righteousnes, or iustification which is by Christ, and without which they could not be iustified, had beene rather to have cast a snare upon them, then to have opened a dore of life and salvation unto them. Well: of Mr. VV. I will speake no evill, for all this leger-de-maine: but if some other man had serv'd me so, I should hardly have refrayned from calling out to him
— 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is,
Ah craftie Mate, clad with bold impudence.
But for Mr. W. —Sit satis ut poenam culpa secunda ferat. that is, 'T shall be enough his next time fault to punish.

It is like indeed, that this will prove but a very small gratification to him his next offence (I feare) is even at the dore. In the meane season my heap of lies mixt with contradictions, is quite vanish'd: and a heap of Mr. Ws. errours, absurdities, false and forged cavillations, left in the stead of it.

The first Argument reduced &c. But here Mr. W. Mr. VV. page 34. stumbles at another heap of manifest and impudent lies: and in the close of his Answere, hee takes his leave with this sweet and courteous salutation: Thus you see how he hath bent his tongue and pen, like a bow for lies, and shootes them forth thick and threefold like poyson'd arrowes, as if his Quiver were the Armory of the Father of lyers, the Prince of darkenesse. Can any man thinke amisse of him, that utters from time to time, such gracious wordes as these? Surely the Prince of darkenesse doth not thinke amisse of him. Well: but I must take spade and shovell in hand, and to worke againe: Mr. W. hath laid a new dunghill before my dore, and I am sure that he that layd it, will not remove it, therefore I my selfe must. The first manifest and impudent lye (which he makes the top or head of this dunghill) is, that I affirme it, to be a strange and harsh expression, to expresse the imputation of Christs righteousnes, by saying that Faith is imputed to men for righteousnes. Suppose it be a mistake▪ to call it a strange and harsh expression, it is farre from being a manifest, and furthest of all, from being an impudent lye, Mr. W. (surely) is mistaken in the poynt of impudence,
here: it is not the lye, but the slaunder that is impudent. But how doth hee prove it to be so much as a mistake, or untruth, that such an expression would be strange and harsh, to carrie that sence, which hee is resolved to force upon it? His demonstrative proofe is this, because it is no strange or harsh expression, to use a figure of speech: and by Faith and beleeving to meane the state, or a man in the state of a true beleever, and by righteousnesse, the state, or a man in the state of righteousnes &c. Mr. Ws. ordinary Readers had need have an Oedipus still at hand, to find out the Enigma's of his proofes and arguments: for poore Davusses have much adoe to understand any thing. It is true, there are many figures of speech, which are no strange or harsh expressions: but first there are few plain and direct expressions (as we have proved this to bee) which will not bee made strange and harsh, if men will metamorphose them into metalepticall and figurative: as the sweetest wine changed, becomes the sharpest vinegar. Secondly, if men will take upon them to coyne new formes of speaking, and will call these, figures, these may well be strange and harsh expressions, which is Mr. Ws. beloved enterprise in this place. He saith and affirmeth, that by Faith and beleeving, to meane the state, or a man in the state of a true beleever, is no strange or harsh expression. I would therefore aske him, whether this would not bee a very strange and harsh expression, to say that Faith is iustified by Faith, his meaning being onely this, that a beleever is iustified by faith. And yet by the rules of his Rhetorick, it should bee but a Divine figure of speech. So againe, whether to say that righteousnes is a member of the mysticall body of Christ, meaning, that a righteous person is such, would not be a strange and harsh expression.

Againe suppose it bee granted, that sometimes the abstract or simple forme, may be used for the concrete,
as righteousnes, for righteous, or justified persons, 2 Cor. 5. 21. so circumcision, for circumcised, Philip. 3. 3. Election, for elected, Rom. 11. 7. and such like, yet to put the act or action, for the agent (as Mr. VV. would here have it, beleeving for the beleever) is more seldome (if at all) found: and consequently the more strange and harsh expression.

Yet again: neither will Mr. Ws. metalepticall oyle, at all mollifie or smooth the harshnesse of the Apostles expression Rom. 4. 3. (though it bee anoynted therewith) if this interpretation be put upon it. Abraham beleeved God (saith the Apostle) and it (that is, this his beleeving God, that is, saith Mr. VV. his state of beleeving, or the beleever himselfe) was imputed to him for righteousnes, that is, for the state of a righteous man.
Qui me in me quaerit, non me, ut me invenerit in me▪ that is,
Who in my selfe shall seeke mee, hardly he
shall in my selfe, like to my selfe, e're find me.

I appeale to all eares that have not quite lost their palate and taste, whether any expression can (lightly) be more strange, harsh, and uncouth, then that which Mr. W. hath put upon the Apostle in this place. Thus you see the first manifest impudent lie (as Mr. W. elegantly phraseth it) is neither lie nor impudent: but onely manifest, and that, a truth.

A second impudent lie (like the former) is, that I say that this figure of speech, (viz. wherewith Mr. W. adorneth, as he thinkes: deformeth, as I thinke, these passages of the Apostle) is not to be found in all the Apostles writings. He should have done well first to have found it, and then it had bin more tolerable to have called it a lie, in him that had denied it. But to call it a manifest and impudent lie, there had beene small reason howsoever: because Mr. W. himselfe, who pretends
to finde it, pretends to find it onely in the utmost corner or nooke of one onely chapter, Rom. 2. and the foure last verses. But what non-sensicall work hee makes with, how he figures and misfigures those passages, we have sufficiently acquainted the Reader from his owne pen formerly.

The third bold lie, and manifest falshood is, that the Apostle time after time useth the phrase of Faith, or beleeving imputed &c. without ever explaining himselfe, or changing his speech. Well: how doth he prove his substantives (for he takes it for granted, it seemes, that his Epithetes must bee abated him in his proofes) how doth he prove either lie or falshood simply, in such an affirmation? yes, ue produceth the 6. and 11. ver. of this chapter, where it is said, that God imputeth righteousnes, and that righteousnes is imputed. Hee might as well have brought forth his letters of Orders, or his licence to preach, and made them his proofe. For these phrases speake not of Faith: and how then should they explaine the imputation of it? yes that which he calleth Faith (saith he) verse 3. and 5. saying there, that it is imputed for righteousnes, here hee explaining himselfe, and changing his speech, calleth it righteousnes. But (good Mr. W.) what doth he call righteousnes, here? that which hee called Faith before, verse 3. and 5. &c. why not rather that which he called righteousnes before? As for example, where he saith, verse 13. that the promise was not given to Abraham, or to his seed, by the Law: why should I rather, by the word Abraham in this place, understand David, mentioned verse 6. then that very Abraham spoken of ver. 1. 2. 3: So by the word righteousnes, verse 6. and 11. why should I rather understand Faith, which is said to be imputed for righteousnes, verse 3. and 5. then that righteousnes it selfe, for (or unto which) Faith is there said to be imputed?

Againe, let Mr. VVs. reason-lesse supposition be admitted,
viz. that by righteousnes in these places, the Apostle meaneth Faith, see what a faire market he hath brought his hogges unto. Vpon this supposition, when the Apostle saith, that God imputeth righteousnes to him that beleeveth, the meaning must be, that God imputeth Faith to him that beleeveth, and so it will bee so farre from being an explaining of himselfe in his former expression, that it will rather obscure what he had directly and plainely said before. But concerning the true importance and meaning of this phrase, imputing righteousnes, wee have discussed it before: where wee found Mr. VV. sitting, quite beside the Cushion. Thus wee see how this souldiour charging his musket deep with powder and browne paper, but wanting bullets, makes terrible cracks onely, but doth no execution at all, except it bee in the recoyle of his engine, upon himselfe.

His second Argument is briefly, &c. Behold a miracle: Mr. VV. page 35 Mr. W. here reasons, and doth not rayle. I hope his powder by this time is well spent: and for the time to come, he will be 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; more soft to handle. It may be his passion being downe, his intellectualls will advance. Well: we must trie him hot and cold. My Argument here riseth thus: That which is imputed for righteousnes, to a beleever, is said to be • his Faith, before it be imputed: but the righteousnes of Christ, is not any mans righteousnes, before it be imputed: Therefore by Faith (in these places) cannot 〈◊〉 meant the righteousnes of Christ.

To this Mr. VV. frames a bimembred answere: t •
first member as ambiguous and impertinent, as the l ••
ter untrue and rea-sonlesse. First hee saith, that t •…
righteousnes of Christ, by spirituall union with Chr •…
is as truely the beleevers as his Faith is. But the q ••
stion betweene my good Friend and me, is not, whether the righteousnesse of Christ, be the beleevers,
〈◊〉 (we are friends in good earnest so farre) nor wh •…
the beleever bee justified by the righteousnes of Christ, but wh • ther it bee his, in such a manner, as it was Christs himselfe, that is, whether he be iustified or made righteous with it, as Christ was, or whether he bee justified, or counted righteous onely for it, and not with it. As a man may be cloathed for his money, but cannot be cloathed with it. So the question is, whether the righteousnes of Christ, be the beleevers cloathing, or garment it selfe, (formally and properly taken) or whether it be the money and price, by which his cloathing and garments were bought. But the Scriptures he brings to prove his first assertion (or part of his answere) are as impertinent for proofe, as the assertion it selfe is to the businesse in hand. To prove the righteousnesse of Christ to be the beleevers, as his Faith is, he miscites those two Scriptures 1 Cor. 1. 30. and 2 Cor. 5. 21. In the first it is said indeed, that Christ is made unto us righteousnes: but what is this to prove, that the righteousnes of Christ is made ours, as our Faith is. The person of Christ, and the righteousnes of Christ, differ toto genere And suppose it had beene said, that the righteousnes of Christ had bin made righteousnes to us, or our righteousnes (which yet are expressions that the Scriptures know not) yet would it not follow, that the righteousnes of Christ must needs be ours, as our Faith is ours. The other Scripture turnes the back upon his purpose, after the same manner. It is onely here said, that beleevers are made the righteousnes of God in Christ: that is, the iustified ones of God, by meanes of Christ, their great sinoffering, and attonement. Here is nothing spoken concerning the righteousnes of Christ, made formally ours by imputation; but onely our iustification meritoriously wrought, and purchased by him, signified.

But secondly he answeres, that this righteousnes of Christ is the beleevers, in order of nature, before it be counted (or imputed) for righteousnes unto him. And this hee proves with this left-handed argument,
that GOD, whose judgement is according to truth, doth not count that to the beleever, which he hath not before, or at the same time doth communicate to him. What is this but that poore trick in Logick, which they call Petitio principii, or begging the Question, right up and downe. He proves the righteousnes of Christ to be the beleevers, before it be imputed to him, because God doth not impute that to him, which he hath not before: where hee takes that for granted which is the Cardo controversiae, viz. that God doth impute the righteousnes of Christ (in his sence) to a beleever. And then againe, here is nothing but Idem per idem, the same thing prov'd by it selfe, (upon the matter) he proves the righteousnes of Christ to be a beleevers, before it is imputed, because God doth not impute it, before it be his. Which is as if he should say: the righteousnes of Christ is a beleevers, before it be imputed, because, before it be his, God doth not impute it. But the positive strength of it is even as little, as the relative: neither is there more truth, then dependance in it. For if the righteousnes of Christ bee the beleevers, before the imputation, to what purpose is the imputation at all? whereof there can be no other reason given, but onely the making that a beleevers, which was not his before. And Mr. VV. himselfe had told us before, page 30. of his discourse, that we are not iustified by the righteousnes of Christ, as it is his, but as it is ours: which ever and anon he affirmeth to be, by communication or imputation. Besides if the righteousnes of Christ be the beleevers, before it be imputed then doth not justification stand in the imputation of Christs righteousnes, but is complete before and without it: for he, whose the righteousnes of Christ is, is (doubtlesse) a iustified person.
Concerning that which he calls his second Answere, more then an Answere hath beene given to it formerly.

In his Answere to my third Argument, hee gently
censures my ignorance in Rhetoricall tropes, and lovingly observes my vaine tergiversation, and ignorantly conceites, that an argument might be fram'd out of the third verse strong against mee. Well: let us pause a while upon these: the S • as are somewhat lower and lesse growne then they were. My argument here is: that the obiect of that faith, which is here said to bee imputed, is God himselfe, or the promise of God, and not the righteousnes of Christ: for to conceive, that by God, is meant the righteousnes of Christ, is to set up a trope, which is not a figure, but a monster of speech. How now doth Mr. VV. answere this, and prove that by God, is here meant the righteousnes of Christ, and that by a Rhetoricall trope, without any strangenesse, or monstrousnes of speech? If he had not a good Friend indeed of the figure Metalepsis, which like a sure pinhorse in his teame, will never faile him at a dead pull, he could never have driven the way hee hath gone, thus farre, and (doubtlesse) would have beene fast in this slow, (how ever yet he recovers himselfe.) But by vertue of this benigne figure, he can make Mercuries statue of any wood, and make plaine, nay elegant and gracefull speech, of such phrases and expressions as would astonish William Lilie, and put Tully and Quintilian halfe besides their Rhetoricall witts. But let us see what Metalepsis, and he can doe together, to cleere the businesse in question. He proves, that by God, who was here the object of Abrahams Faith (for, he beleeved God: and that, it was imputed unto him for righteousnes) is to bee understood the righteousnes of Christ, thus: because no man in beleeving by a true faith can separate Christs satisfaction and righteousnes from Christ himselfe: If he enjoyes Christ himselfe, he enjoyes his benefits also &c. Dicite Io Paean: Strike up a triumph. Because a man cannot in beleeving separate the righteousnes of Christ from Christ, therefore by the word God, must necessarily bee understood the
righteousnes of Christ. But first I mervaile why Mr. W. throughout this whole discourse, still mentions the satisfaction of Christ, with the righteousnes of Christ: wheras I never to this day, so much as thought of, or intended the least difference, or dispute about the satisfaction of Christ, but onely about his active obedience to the Law, whether this bee so imputed to a beleever, that by vertue of this imputation, hee may claime Heaven in right of the first Covenant, doe this and live, that is, whether a beleever bee formally righteous with Christs righteousnes imputed, or no: Therefore his importune mention, and thrusting in the passive obedience or satisfaction of Christ, from place to place, without any occasion or necessity, can argue nothing else, but an exulcerate desire, to represent mee to the world, as an enemy or denyer of Christs satisfaction.

But secondly, what though a man cannot separate the righteousnes of Christ from Christ himselfe in beleeving? doth it therefore follow, that the righteousnes of Christ must needs be the object of Faith, as justifying? much lesse doth it follow, that this righteousnes of Christ, must needs be signified, either by the word, God, or by the promise of God concerning Christ (which himselfe granteth to have beene the object of Abrahams Faith in this place.) A man cannot separate the soule of Christ, or the members of his humane body; from Christ himselfe in beleeving: yet neither the soule of Christ, nor any member of his body is the object of Faith, as justifying. For then whosoever beleeved Christ had a soule, or a head, hands &c. should be justified. Besides, it is not altogether so true (as perhaps he thinks it is) that the righteousnes of Christ, cannot be separated from Christ himselfe, in beleeving, at least from Christ considered, as the object of justifying faith. The Turkes at this day beleeve Christ to have beene a righteous man, and consequently beleeve his righteousnes: yet doe they not beleeve in Christ himselfe, justifyingly.

As for that which followeth in the remainder of his answere to this argument, &c. as his charge of vaine tergiversation, of bringing Scriptures to confute my selfe with the rest, I conceive them to bee of that manifest inconsequence and indigestednesse, that I had rather trust my Reader with his owne apprehensions concerning them, then adventure to trouble him with any long confutation. Quilibet ignavus praecipitata premit. that is,
What of it selfe is tumbling downe,
With little strength downe may be throwne.

Christs righteousnes, can in no tollerabe sence, be calledMr. W. p. 38. that Faith, whereby Abraham beleeved in God, who quickneth the dead. This is my next Argument, to prove that by the word, Faith, in these passages, is not meant the active obedience of Christ. And how doth Mr. W. deliver himselfe out of the hand of this enemie? by this charme: because God neither quickned Christ, nor raised him from the dead, till he had fulfilled all righteousnes. If this be an Answere, much joy may Mr. W. and his friends have of it. Onely let me say this to him: that neither did God raise up Christ from the dead, till he had layne three dayes and three nights in the grave: and yet I conceive Mr. W. will hardly find his lying three dayes and three nights in the grave, any where called Faith, or signified by that expression.

But Quoniam vult Alexander Deus esse, Deus esto. that is,
Since Alexander needs a God will be,
(Much good, may't doe him) a God let him be,

My fift Argument was: Abrahams Faith, which was imputed to him, was such a Faith, wherein hee was not weake, neither doubted of Gods promise &c. ver. 19.
20. This can be no description of the righteousnes of Christ. Ergo &c. How are we beaten out of this field? with this wodden dagger: The more strong Abraham was in Faith &c. the more firmely he was united to Christ, and had more full communion of his righteousnes &c. therefore this argument makes against me. I think (indeed) the argument, as much as the Answere, and both alike. The Question is not, whether Abraham had communion with Christ in his righteousnes, or no, either more full or lesse full: but whether that which is here spoken and affirmed concerning Abrahams faith, can with any possible congruitie of speech, be applyed to the righteousnes of Christ, and be conceived, as spoken of that. Was that Faith, whereby Abraham doubted not of Gods promise, the righteousnes of Christ? or rather was not the promise of God, that whereby Abraham doubted not of Christs righteousnes? But my Antagonist starts one new notion in Divinity, which I doe not remember that I have met with all either from the pen or mouth of any Divine hitherto. viz. degrees in justification. For that expression, communion with Christ in his righteousnes, is still used to signifie justification: and therefore if Abraham, by meanes of the strength of his Faith, had fuller communion with Christ in his righteousnes, then other beleevers have, hee must needs bee more justified then they: and consequently their justification by Christ must be imperfect.

My next argument he turnes over with the same wet finger. The argument was this: Abrahams beleeving, that God who had promised, was able to performe, was the Faith imputed to him. But this was not Christs righteousnes. Ergo. This Mr. VV. confuteth (or rather confirmeth) by this Answere: The more that Abraham rested on Gods power &c The more communion he had of Christs righteousnes, and the more justly did God count him for a righteous man, and impute
Christs righteousnes unto him. I thought to have turn'd Argument and Answere loose together; and to have suffered them, each to stand, or fall, by their owne strength, without bringing in any second to umpire: but that there is an ill sounding phrase or two in the answere, which (at best) deserve rods, if not Scorpions. Besides the repetition of that expression, censured (and that for no good) in the former answere, hee useth such streyns as these, that the more Abraham rested on Gods power, the MORE JVSTLY did God count him a righteous man, and impute Christs righteousnes to him. Which let Charity her selfe be the interpres, cannot but imply, that God doth with lesse justice count a weak beleever, a righteous man, and with lesse iustice impute the righteousnes of Christ unto him, then to a strong. I know if Mr. W. had me thus upon the hipp, I should bee violently throwne upon my back, and beaten when I were downe, with the fist of lies, heresie, blasphemy &c. but I will let him gently downe and onely advise him betweene him and mee, to speake more advisedly and considerately hereafter.

My next Argument is: That Faith which God imputes to us for righteousnes, is said to bee, our beleeving on him which rais'd Christ from the dead. But the righteousnes of Christ, is not our beleeving on him which rais'd Christ from the dead. Ergò. How doth Mr. W. fence this blow? Crimine ab uno-Disce omnes: Hee that one Answere hath of his, hath all. I cannot properly say that which hee answereth, but that which hee here saith, is this: our beleeving in God who raised Christ from the dead, is our assureance that Christ hath made full satisfaction for us, and therefore the righteous, God, who raised him up, is satisfied for us, and hath accepted his righteousnes for our righteousnesse, and &c. concluding thus. Therefore this is for us, and not against us. Surely a Shoomaker might as well sell Scabberds for Shooes, as Scholars
put off Arguments with such impertinent discourses as these, instead of Answers; For what is there in all this to prove (or so much as to colour over a proofe) that by that Faith which is described to be our beleeving on him that raised Christ from the dead, must needs be meant the righteousnes, or active obedience of Christ? or what reasonable man is there under Heaven, that can imagine, that the Apostle intending to describe the righteousnes of Christ, should describe it thus: The righteousnes of Christ is our beleeving on him, that raised up Christ from the dead. This is the quintessence & extract of Mr. Ws. answer.
My eight (and last Argument) either he or his Scribe so defaceth in the laying it downe, that it rather lookes like one of his Answers, then any of my Arguments.

He calls it, a bare affirmation, that to take faith in a proper sense, is more Plaine and cleere, and better - beleeving the Apostle in this discourse, where he largely handles the point of iustification. Indeed if this were my Argument, Mr. Ws. Answer would serve. The summe of my Argument, (more at large opened in my papers) is this, The point or question of imputation in iustification, being onely handled in this passage of Scripture, and no where else explained; it is no waies probable, but that the Apostle should speake somewhat distinctly, and plainely, of the nature of it: otherwise he might seeme rather desirous to lay a stumbling in the way, then to write any thing for the learning and comfort of Christians, &c. To this Mr. W. answereth mum. Onely he gravely instructeth us, that it is more comfortable for us to rest on Christs righteousnesse, &c. then to build on Faith, which in the best is mingled, and stained with many doubtings oftentimes. Therefore the Apostle undoubtedly intends Christs righteousnes; and so he doth expresse in plaine words (to another purpose) cap 5, 19. and 10. 4.

In which words he maketh an opposition betweene things of the most direct and essentiall subordination that
can be, (and which doe inseparably involve one the other) viz. r • sting on Christs righteousnes, and building on Faith. It is impossible that any man should build on Faith, that doth not rest on Christs righteousnes, that is, the satisfaction that he hath made: because Faith is a resting on this satisfaction. And so againe: a resting on Christs righteousnes, includes a building on Faith; For who is there that will or can rest upon this righteousnes, except he beleeves, that such a resting or beleeving as this▪ will stand him in stead? Sure I am, that Paul built upon Faith, for his iustification, as well as on the righteousnes of Christ himselfe (as Mr. Ws. beloved phrase is) though in a different manner, (which hath been formerly explained) when he said: We know that a man is not iustified by the works of the Law, but by the Faith of Iesus Christ, and have beleeved in Iesus Christ, that we might be iustified by the faith of Christ, &c. Gal. 2. 16. And as Christ speaketh concerning himselfe, Iohn 12. 44. He that beleeveth in me, beleeveth not in me, but in him that sent me: that is, not so much in me, as in him that sent me: So may it be sayd, that he that buildeth on faith, buildeth not on faith, but on the truth and faithfulnes of him, who hath promised forgivenesse of sinnes and salvation to him that beleeveth. And for the mixture or stayning of faith with many doubtings this is no consideration at all, to deferre or keepe a man from building upon it, if it be a faith unfeigned and true: because there is the same iustification and salvation promised to the weakest faith, and to the strongest.

After these Arguments &c. In this passage he pretends,Mr. W. p. 39. to countermine and dissolve the Answers I give to those places, where the words, faith, and hope, are used to signify their obiect. And here I am arrested againe by this troublesome Bayliffe, for notable tergiversation. I know not what he calls tergiversation: he that reades the passage glanced at by him, wil • hardly say, that either I betray, or turne my back upon the cause
I undertake. But if that be tergiversation, to dissemble and turne the back upon the maine strength of those things which are pretended to be answered, and onely to catch and snatch here and there, where any word seemes to lye a little loose: then I may truely say, that the Fox is the finder, and the tergiversator is, from whence the accusation comes. I will not be so troublesome to my Reader here, as to relate the passage hee strikes at: there are some copies thereof, in some mens hands, and more (I conceive) may be taken upon this occasion, but the substance of the answere he gives to this passage, consists (chiefly) of 2 or 3 untruths. As first, where he saith, that especially the act of belieefe and hope, are to be understood, Gal. 1. 22 & 3. 23. Col. 1. 5. Cujus contrarium verum est. 2. where he saith that he hath prov'd the righteousnes or active obedience of Christ, to be the object of Faith, as justifying: whereas he hath not in all his discourse, made the least haire of that head, either black or white. 3. (and lastly) where he affirmes this righteousnesse of Christ, to be the onely proper object of Faith, as iustifying: whereas it hath been evictingly demonstrated, that it is neither the proper, nor lesse proper obiect thereof, as such, and also that the Scriptures no where speake so of it. And yet as the Israelites when they had made their golden Calfe, were not satisfied therewith, but rejoyced over the work of their owne hands, and eate and drank and played before it. So neither doth this man content himselfe, to speake his pl • asure in untruths, but boldly concludes thus insultingly and triumphantly, over what he had sayd against me. Thus he shamefully trifles to shew his impudencie, and perversnes. If he that trifles most, or shewes most impudency, and perversnesse, should forfaite hi •
learning to the other, I beleeve Mr. W. would soone be as ignorant in Rhetorique, as I am; and I every whit as skillfull and expert as he.

div.head: The fourth way of confirmation, &c.
div.p:
Now we come to the fift and last act of our Tragoedie. M. W. p. 40. Where before he comes to answere all my testimonies at once, he hath a great mind to get up into Gods Throne, and there to act the Divels part. For whereas I ingenuously confessed that I had not read all the testimonies
• produced in the Authors themselves, (neither indeed is my poore Library so well furnished) he first undertakes to know my heart and intent, (which is the prerogative of God) and then against all reasonable and charitable construction, of my ingenuous confession, he chargeth me, not to have made it out of humility, and modesty, but out of Satanicall subtilty, to vent my poysonfull lies under the person of another, as the Divel did vent his, by the Serpent. Gen. 3. (and now doth by Mr. W. his successor) which is the expresse part and practise of the Divel. Iob. 1. 9. 11.
The reason (I conceive) why he could think no better of that my Confession, then to be made out of subtiltie, was the faultinesse of the Standerd in his owne bosome.

The reason why the reviling Scribes, and Pharises, concluded against Christ, now hanging on the Crosse, that he could not save himselfe, (Mat. 27. 42.) was onely (or chiefly) this, because if they had bin able to save themselves, they would have done it upon the like occasion.

div.head: An Answere to all his Testimonies, &c.
div.p:
To all? nay (quoth Bolton) bate me an ace? ThereM. W. a p. 41. ad finem. are 17 whereunto there is nothing at all answered: In the meane time:
Quid dignum tanto ferat hic promissor hiatu? that is,
What shall this promise-maker have,
In reward of this promise brave?

The old proverb here workes. Parturiunt montes, nascetur ridiculus mus. that is,
The Mountaines were in travaile sore,
The birth's a Mouse, and nothing more

But first he whets his courage upon the hone of indignation, and rageth (after his wonted manner) against my impudent boasting, of the generall consent of Interpreters, and inferres, that a more odious example, of impudencie and folly, cannot be imagined, then here I make my selfe, by making m •
f • lly and absurdity, to strive for Master-ship with my impudence. I see I shall have new Liveries from my Mr. before my old be quire worne up. Well, I beleeve, that a more odious example, both of impudencie and folly, may not onely be imagined, but visibly demonstrated, and pointed at with the finger, I know where. And for Mr. Ws. railing and reviling speeches, they are (at the best) but like Silver in Solomons dayes, which for the abundance of it, was nothing worth. But except either much learning, or somewhat else, had set him and his wits at odds, he could never have affirmed, that no one Orthodox Divine either ancient or later, ever understood, by Faith imputed for righteousnes, Faith in a proper sence, but the satisfaction
and righteousnes of Christ himselfe. I make no question but he takes in himselfe (whosoever else he thrusts out) into the number of Orthodox Divines: and how oft hath he, in former passages of this very discourse, (as hath beene observed) affirmed the very selfe same thing himselfe, in as ample and expresse termes, as I doe.

As for this last quarter of his worthy piece, which concern's Authors and testimonies, I shall bee very briefe in framing m • reply unto it: because I verily beleeve, that the Author himselfe would have spared it, had hee but rightly understood the opinion against which hee hath armed himselfe with so much fury, and what is meant by Faith in a proper sence.

Concerning the testimonies which he himselfe brings forth out of the rich magazine of his Library and learning, because they are so pregnant and pertinent to prove that which no man questions, viz. justification by the righteousnes and satisfaction of Christ, in a meritorious way, and doe not so much as touch or come neere the point in controversie, (except it be in way of contradiction to him that produceth them) I take my leave of them (at once) and wish them rest and peace. Onely I cannot but take speciall notice of a very strange piece of Divinitie (wheresoever he had it) which drops from him in those passages where he speakes so much to so little purpose, and some things with as little truth) concerning Calvin: Here he teacheth, that sinnes of comm • ssion, are taken away by that part of Christs satisfaction imputed, which is called his passive obedience, or voluntary suffering the penalty of the Law: and sins of omission by his active obedience, in fulfilling the righteousnesse which the Law requires, which is the other part of Christs imputed satisfaction. Mr. W. talkes much (as we have heard) of heapes of lies, of heresies, blasphemies &c. but here we have a Lernaean Lake of hideous and portentous Divinity, things which I should have conceived, that Mr. W. would not have received
though an Angel from Heaven should have brought them unto him.

First he affirmes the taking away of sinnes of omission, by the active obedience of Christ onely: whereas the Scriptures teach expressely, that without shedding of blood, there is no remission. (Heb. 9. 22.) neither of sinnes of commission nor of omission. So 1 Ioh. 1. 7. The bloud of Iesus Christ his Sonne, cleanseth us from ALL sinne: not of commission onely, but of omission also. Againe, Rev. 1. 5. Vnto him that loved us, and washed us from our sins in his bloud. So Rom. 4. 25. who was deliverd to death for our sins &c. The Scripture never mentioneth any purging or taking away of sinne, but by the blood, death and sufferings of Christ: neither doth it give the least intimation of any distinction or difference to be made (in this respect) betweene sinnes of omission, and commission. Neither is there any colour or appearance of difference betweene them, in reference to their purgation and attonement, there being many sinnes of omission, which are much more heynons and grievous, then many sinnes of Commission.

Secondly, he makes the active obedience or righteousnes of Christs life, of like consideration, with his death and passive obedience, viz. penall and satisfactory: as if to live righteously and holily, had bin a punishment layd upon Christ, to make satisfaction for all the sinnes of Omission, whereas himselfe affirmeth, that it was his meate, (not his punishment) to doe the will of him that sent him. Iohn 4. 34. The Papists indeed make prayer, and other their serving God, penall and satisfactory: but (as Solomon saith, Prov. 21. 15,) It is ioy to the iust to do iudgement, and Iob that he put on righteousnes and it covered him, and iudgement was a robe and Diademe unto him, Iob. 29. So generally when the heart is renued by grace, and brought to an inward and habituall conformity with the Law of God, wayes of righteousnes and holines, are wayes of pleasure, and of intire contentment. Much more then
must it needs be conceived; that the Lord Christ, being full of grace and truth, and having the Spirit without measure (as the Scripture witnesseth) and not the least reluctation in the frame of his Heart and soule against any holy Commadement or way of God, tooke very high and rich contentment, in all those wayes of holinesse, wherein hee walked, and exercised himselfe all his dayes: yet is it not denyed in all this, but that this active obedience of Christ, may in some sence and respect, be called satisfactory too, viz. as concurring and falling in with its influence into the bloud or death of Christ, but not in and by it selfe. And this our Saviour himselfe teacheth, Iohn 12. 24. Except the corne of wheat fall into the ground and die, it abideth alone: that is, Christ by his active obedience, and the righteousnesse of his life, had iustified none but himselfe, without his death: but if it dye, (saith hee) it bringeth forth much fruit, that is, so holy and righteous a person as Christ was in his life, by his death iustifieth many. Hence it is, that the Scriptures so frequently when they mention the death of Christ, for the redemption, or expiation of the sinnes of men, still mention his holinesse or the righteousnes of his life with it. For Christ also hath suffered for sinnes, the IVST for the uniust, 1 Pet. 3. 18. So 1 Pet. 1 18. 19. knowing that you were not redeemed with corruptible things, &c. but with the precious bloud of Christ, as of a Lamb undefiled, and without spot: See Heb. 9. 14. and 1 Pet. 2. 21. 22. even as those qualifications, of age, Sex, spotlessenes, soundnesse &c. required in the legall sacrifices, were expiatory (in their kind) when the Beast came to be offreed and slaine, but not before.

Thirdly (and lastly, and which is of the worst, and indeed of desperate consequence) by dividing the satisfaction of Christ into parts, he utterly destroyes and abolisheth the infinitenesse thereof. For that which may be divided, must needs be finite: and that which is but the part of another, cannot it selfe be infinite. And
as certaine it is, that that whose parts are finite, cannot it selfe be infinite. If hee will maintaine the active part of Christs satisfaction (as his Rhetoricall expression is) to be infinite (which is the more consonant to his principles) why might not the sinnes of the world, as well of commission, as omission, have beene fully expiated, and taken away thereby? Certainly no sinne, nor sinnes, can require more then an infinite satisfaction. And if this active satisfaction be infinite, and consequently sufficient to take away the sinnes of the world: what necessitie can there be conceived of the passive satisfaction, if the worke and intent thereof be otherwise performed. I doe not frustrate the grace of God (saith Paul) for if righteousnes be by the Law, then Christ is dead in vaine. Gal. 2. 21. It is as true, concerning the Law performed by Christ, as by men themselves: if the righteousnes or iustification of the world be by Christs active obedience, and performance of the Law, his death must be in vaine. If I doe not lay on loade upon Mr. W. here, and heate the furnace of my censure seven times hotter then ordinary, let him say that he scap'd a scouring, when time was.

My last labour (in this my Replye) is to vindicate the testimonies, produced by me out of severall Authors, as well ancient and moderne, for the further establishing and confirmation, of the Imputation of Faith in a direct and proper sence, in those controverted passages of the Apostle, Rom. 4. And here had we not to doe with men of wilfull and importune spirits, that conceit they have a dispensation from the Figure Metalepsis, to kick the nominative case and the verb out of dores; the bare recitall and laying downe the sayings themselves, were an abundant vindication of them in that behalfe. Or if wee had to do with a man that would stand his ground, and owne his owne opinion when it is at the best, this labour might be spared altogether. For Mr. W. (as hath beene more then once observed) hath more then
once ratified and sealed to that very interpretation, for the ratification whereof these testimonies are brought forth by me. But his infirmity is, Fluctuation,
Nunc hùc, nunc illue, exemplo nubis aquosae. that is,
Much like a Waterish cloud, which now is here,
And by and by the windes will have it there.

Howsoever, I shall be very succinct and briefe in my demonstrations, being full of confidence, that every man that is not Mr. W. will be very easily satisfied in the point▪ Concerning these testimonies in generall, I desire to propound but this one consideration, to any reasonable and considering man: whether it bee so much as tollerably credible, or probable in the least and lowest degree of probability, that so many learned Interpreters, one succeeding other thorough so many generations, and undertaking to expound a Scripture which they conceived to be figurative and tropicall, nay (as Mr. W. contends for) hypertropicall, where there should bee figure upon figure, and trope upon trope, should none of them give warning, or so much as take notice of any tropicall expression, but deliver their mindes and judgements concerning the places, in the very same terme, and word, wherein the trope upon trope, should lye. Credat Iudaus Apella, Non ego. that is,
This let the circumcised Iew,
Beleeve, instead of me, for true:

Especially considering that it is the manner of Interpreters, when they came to any tropicall and figurative expression so conceived and apprehended by them, though the figure be ten times more obvious (then it can be in the Scriptures controverted, if there were any)
yet either to give notice of the figure by Name, or at least to set downe in more plaine and expresse words, what is meant by the figurative expression in the Scriptures: neither of which is done, by any of the Authors cited by mee upon those places; but still, that which Paul saith was imputed to Abraham, viz his beleeving God, or his Faith, the same say these interpreters also: yea some of them emphatically, seeking (as it were) to bind their Reader to the very word and terme of Faith, which the Apostle useth, and not suffering them to cast about in their mindes or thoughts, for any other thing. As in the testimony cited from Bucer: Abraham fidem habuit Iehovae, &c. that is, Abraham beleeved God, and it was imputed to him for righteousnes, that is (saith Bucer) hee accounted this FAITH, or BELEEVING to him for righteousnes. If he had ever once imagined, the righteousnes of Christ to have beene that, which was imputed to Abraham for righteousnes, and not Abrahams faith in a proper sence, would he have expressed himselfe in such a manner? So in that cited from Bullinger: Concredidit se Abraham Deo &c. that is, Abraham committed himselfe unto God by beleeving, & illud ipsum &c. that is, that VERY SAME THING was imputed to him for righteousnes. He that will here by illud ipsum, that VERY SAME THING understand the righteousnes of Christ, must seeke his substantive to his adjective hee knowes not where, and when he hath found it, will break poore Priscians head with it too. Again, in that other testimony cited from the same Author, upon Gal. 3. 6. imputatum est ei &c. hoc est, ILLA IPSA ABRAHAE FIDES, ipsi ad justitiam imputatum est, that is, it was imputed to him for righteousnes: that is, this very SELFE SAME FAITH OF ABRAHAM, was imputed to him for righteousnes. Surely though Mr. W. makes bold, to understand by faith, the righteousnes of Christ (where be pleaseth) yet by the Faith of Abraham, he will not adventure to understand the righteousnes of Christ, least hee should sinne against
the reputation and credit of his owne understanding too farre. In these and sundry other testimonies yet remaining a man of very reasonable apprehension cannot but conceive, that the Authors, with as much anxiety and warines of speech, as well they could use, excluded all other things whatsoever, (without exception) from this imputation, but onely that VERY SELFE SAME FAITH of Abraham, in the proper literall, and most usuall and obvious sence and signification. This for the first demonstration, which concerns the testimonies in generall, whereby it appeares, through and through all that thick mist of wordes and passion which Mr. W. hath cast upon it to obscure and darken it, that the Authors generally by me alledged upon these Scriptures, did not understand the word, FAITH, or BELEEVING, in a tropicall or metalepticall sence, for the righteousnes of Christ, but in a proper, plaine, and direct sence, for that grace or act of Faith, by which Abraham through the worke and assistance of the Holy Ghost beleeved in God.

The latter demonstration, will not (I take it) extend so far as the former did, to include all the testimonies without exception: but as farre as it will reach, which is to many of them, it makes the matter greater then contradiction; that their Authors in their commentaries and expositions, could not possibly take the word Faith, or BELEEVING in a figurative or metalepticall sence, but in a proper. The demonstration is this: because the word FAITH, taken in a figurative sence for the righteousnesse of Christ, will make them speake partly manifest and open blasphemy, partly most ridiculously and absurdly: As for example, in that cited from Luther, on Gal. 3. 6. Deus reputat istam IMPERFECTAM FIDEM &c. that is, God for Christs sake, in whom I have begun to beleeve, accounts this IMPERFECT FAITH, for perfect righteousnes: If by FAITH here, we understand the righteousnes of Christ, and not Faith properly, we make Luther an execrable Blasphemer: for then he calls the righteousnesse
of Christ, an imperfect righteousnes. So in that of Illyricus, Mendica illa fides, &c. that is, that SAME BEGGERLY FAITH, apprehending the righteousnes of Christ, was imputed unto him, instead of his owne righteousnesse. I • here by the word, Faith, wee shall understand the righteousnes of Christ, wee make this Author first to speake abhominable blasphemy, in calling the righteousnes of Christ, a beggerly righteousnes: and secondly most ridiculously and absurdly, in saying, the righteousnesse of Christ apprehending the righteousnes of Christ, was imputed unto him &c. So in that of Calvin. Fides reputatur in justitiam, non quòd ullum à nobis meritum afferat &c. that is, Faith is imputed for righteousnes, not because it brings any merit from us, but because it apprehends the goodnesse of God. If by Faith here, which this Author affirmeth to be imputed for righteousnes, we shall understand the righteousnes of Christ: then we must suppose him to give this reason, why this righteousnesse of Christ should be imputed to us for righteousnes, viz. because it brings no merit with it from us, but because it apprehends the goodnes of God, both which are very ridiculous (if the one be not blasphemous.) I might include many other of the testimonies within the compasse of this demonstration: but I judge by my selfe, that my Reader •
would gladly be at his journeyes end. Wherefore if Mr. W. who so confidently affirm's, that of all the testimonies by me cited, there is not one that affirmes, that Faith (taken in a proper sence) is imputed for righteousnes, and calls me the most odious example of impudency and folly that can be imagined, for saying the contrary, will willingly and patiently from his own pen, be content to beare himself the imputation of this odious exemplarinesse both in impudency and folly, I conceive it may doe him much good for the time to com • : but my pen is mercifull, and shall cast no such imputation upon him, though hee deserves it. And for those bloody crimes, of forgery and false subornation of witnesses, Mr.
VV. is pleased out of his lenity and clemency, to content himselfe with the bare charge and accusation: but doth not prosecute his inditement, nor once goeth about to prove, that I have forged so much as the least jot, or title in any of the testimonies alledged by me, fearing (it seemes) that he should make no earnings of that labour.

I must yet adde a little, concerning some rare passages in the very last page, of his discourse. This is one speciall commendation of his tragicall choler, that it doth not in extremo actu deficere, faile or faint in the last act, but is in very good plight and liking, and brings forth more fruit, then at the first. He first gravely admonisheth all indifferent Readers, and zealous Christians, of two grand duties: first to take heed to themselves, and then to admonish others, to have no fellowship with so openly profest Socinian Heretiques, &c. Next hee calls the opinion I maintaine a wicked and blasphemous heresie: then he aggravates an offence that is not, by affirming that which was not, viz. our persisting in our pestilent heresie, notwithstanding many admonitions given by divers grave and learned Divines, and often publique confutations and censures &c. (The man had as good have told me, that the man in the moone drinks Claret I know as much of the one, as of the other) Next, he methodically proceeds, to make a fierce outcry against me, as a desperate man, wilfully, and against the knowne light, and against my owne conscience, proclaiming Luther, Calvin, &c. to be of my opinion &c. and so hee goeth on beating, and te • ring himselfe, like a wild Bull in a Net, Foaming out his owne shame (after his wonted manner) till he hath satiated himselfe, with railing, and speaking evill, both of persons and things, which he knoweth not: Onely in the end and catastrophe of his tragique piece as if he envied Apuleius, his merry tales of his golden Asse, or Ovid▪ his pleasant Fables in his▪ Metamorphosis: he contrives a Gorgonean fiction, with much curiosity, and quaintnes, of device:
How I and my followers, proclaiming our pedigree from the Father of liers, should make false reports. How that Mr. Goodwin did confute and confound him, (whereas he can do both himselfe, to himselfe) and did mightily convince him▪ by the power of his Arguments; and (as followes in his most hideous and piteous complaint.) Hoc animis natum, inventum{que} Poema juvandis. that is,
This Poem (doubtlesse) bred was, and contriv'd,
To please the fancies of men much agriev'd.

For my part—
Esse canes utero sub virginis, esse Chimaeram,
Sphyngá{que}, et Harpyas, serpentiferos{que} Gigantes,
Centimanum{que} Gygem, tergeminum{que} canem;
Haec ego cuncta priús &c.
that is,
I sooner shall beleeve, that bawling Dogs,
Are in the Virgins bellie, and those hobbs,
Chimera hight and Sphynx, that monster rare,
With ravening Harpyes, and that Gyants are;
Like Serpents footed, and that Gyges had
An hundred hands, and Cerb'rus triple head.

I confesse, men may be foolish, and take pleasure in the vanity of their tongues, and sending abroad reports of strange shapes and figures, into the world: but for those in whose faces Mr. W. spits out his gall, calling them, rude, impudent, & unmannerly: I fully beleeve they have so much of their wits yet unshaken, and remaining, as is sufficient to preserve them from any such ridiculous exorbitance of tongue, as the pen of exorbitancie here would fasten upon them. Notwithstanding, if any of them have committed that high Treason, they here stand
charged with, against the princely dignity of Mr. Ws. reputation; he shall do well to call them to account for it. It were no hard matter for him to trace the report by the footsteps, and follow it home to the very mouth, out of which it first issued: and I beleeve, before he came to the fourth or fift man, the Author would be found. In the meane season (if Mr. W. please) my Books, to his, that it was some of his owne followers or friends (that I do not say of his Cloath too) and not mine, that made the wooden Image he speaks of: though neither can I thinke, but that he hath bestowed much cost in garnishing, and polishing it himselfe, and that when it came, it came but rough into his hands, in comparison of those goodly ornaments of Rhetorique, which he hath now put upon it. Facile est inventis addere, that is, Once invented, soone augmented.

From cursing and reviling, he falls to praying, that God would defend his Church and People, from such spirits (which no where molest or hurt them) and thinking it high time to repent at last, he gives glory to God: I remember Squire, when he clap'd poyson upon the pummel of Queene Elizabeths Saddle, to take away her life, cried out alowd, God save the Queene. But if Mr. W. indeed, desires to give glory to God, he must repent of his forged accusations, his slanderous reports, of his rage and fiercenesse, against those that never wronged him in the least matter: he must retract and cancell the greatest part of what he hath sent abroad in this his scandalous Pamphlet, viz. all the palpable errors and untruths therein, whose name may be called Legion, for they are many. And for this so solemn, anxious, and laborious an acquitting himselfe, from joyning or submitting to the truth, he might have spared it, without much danger of prejudice to him. For those that know him (as who do • h not?) know him to have Pelidae stomachum cedere nesci •• i. Achilles stomack sto • t▪ that knowes not how to yield, no more to truth then to error, but onely
to what hath already surprized his fancie and imagination.

The Lord who alone is the giver of new hearts, unto men, give him a heart to do all this, and whatsoever besides belongs to his peace, or may through him, tend to advance the glorious Gospel of Jesus Christ, in the world. If he shall yet write more Bookes against me, if they be not too big, I will lay them upon my shoulder (as Iob speaketh) but here make him a solemne promise, that I will never anti-pamphlet with him more. If he be wilfull and resolved to have the last word, I shall not envy him the glory and priveledge of a skould.
